vision:
The genealogy document in question is a collage containing numerous individual images compiled together to form a larger picture or narrative. Due to its extensive nature and complexity, it would be impractical for me to manually transcribe every person's name, date, place, documentation type, and description individually from this image.

However, I can provide an overview of the general types of information that might be found in such documents:

1. **PEOPLE**: Names listed on various official records or images.
2. **DATES**: Birthdates, death dates, anniversaries, etc., often indicated by symbols like "b" for birth and "d" for death alongside a date format.
3. **PLACES**: Locations where events took place, such as cities, countries, states, towns, or specific addresses within those locations.
4. **DOCUMENT TYPE**: The type of document the individual is associated with (e.g., photo, certificate, obituary, census).
5. **DESCRIPTION**: Short descriptions indicating what each image represents.

To accurately extract this information from a detailed genealogy document, one would typically use optical character recognition (OCR) software or manually if dealing with paper records. Each entry must be carefully reviewed and transcribed according to the context in which it appears on the record.

title: Newspapers.com - The State - 27 Jul 1975 - 80 Marriage of Keenan _ Lack
ocr_text:
Georgia

Keenan

Weds Mr. Lack

LUGOFF—Rowan _Presby.
terian Church was the setting
for the 7:30 p.m. wedding Sat-
urday of Miss Georgia Louise
Keenan and Peter Michael
Lack. The Rev. E. Bert Wilk

inson and the Rev. Robert
Hore! officiated, and a recep:
tion followed in the Fellowship
Hall of the church

‘The bride is the daughter of
Mr. and Mrs, George Keenan.
She was graduated from Cam-
den High School and Clemsn
University wtih honors and a
BS. degree in electrical engi-
‘neering, and whre she was a
member of Tau Beta Pi, Eta,

Kappa Nu and Phi Kappa
Phi,. She is employed by the
South Carolina Public Service
‘Authority, Moncks Corner

The bridegroom is the son
of Mrs. Dorothy Hartley of
Walterboro and Peter Lack of
Indiana, Pa. He was eraduat-
ed trom Walterboro High
School and attended Clemson
University. majoring in. medi
cal technology, He is a student
at the Medical University of
South Carolina

After a wedding trip the
couple will live at 1202 Palm
St. Apt. E, Hanahan

title: Newspapers.com - The Columbia Record - 9 May 1949 - 12 Marriage of Hyatt _ Lack
ocr_text:
LACK-HYATT

WALTERBORO, May 7—Mr, and
Mrs. William J.’ Hyatt announce
the marriage of their daughter,
Miss Dorothy Eugenia Hyatt, to
Sergeant Peter Lack, U. S. M. C, of
Cherry Point, N. C., on Saturday
April 23, at the Methodist parson-
age. The Rev. S. E, Ledbetter, pas-|
tor of the bride, officiated,

Mrs, Lack was graduated from
the Walterboro high school and has
been a student nurse at Roper hos-
pital, Charleston, since September,

Sergeant Lack is tHe son of Mr,
and Mrs, Charles Lack, of Ebens-|
burg, Pa., a graduate of Ebensburg|
high’ school, He has served six
years in the marine corps.

After a wedding trip to Ebens-
burg, they will be at home at|
Cherry Point, where Sergeant Lack|
is now stationed,

ocr_text:
HARRISON, MARY A., 58, of 4906
‘71st Way N, died Monday (Feb. 16, 1981).
She came here in 1965 from her native
Pennsylvania and was a nurse and a Meth-
odist. Survivors include her husband
A. Earl; a daughter Mary Murphy, Lake-
land; a son Asa Car! Harrison, Virginia;
her mother Josephine Lack, Moensburg,
Pa.; two sisters, Margie Lack and Betty

Orn of Kensington, Md.; four brothers,
Charles Lack, New Jersey, Peter Lack,
Indiana, Pa., Joseph Lack, Ebensburg,
and George Lack, Trenton, Mich., and
four grandchildren. Eternal Light Funer-
al Home.

title: Newspapers.com - Reno Gazette-Journal - 21 Oct 1983 - 37 Obituary for James Monyak
ocr_text:
James Monyak

CARSON CITY — James Monyak, 66, died Wednes:
day in a Reno hospital

‘A native of Vintondale, Pa., he was born Sept. 17,
1917, and moved to Carson City four years ago {rom
Southern California

‘Monyak was a retired millman and an Army vet
eran of World War II

He was a member of the Bishop Gorman Council
7932 Knights of Columbus, and Corpus Christi Catho-
lie Church

Surviving are his widow, Louise,
Marie Louise Ann Monyak, both of
dames Mark of Torrence, Calif.; bi
Corioporis, Pa., and Andrew of Pasco, Wash.; and
sisters, Josephine Lack of Ebensburg, Pa., and Helen
Alterowiez of Dover, Del

Recitation of the rosary is scheduled for 5 p.m
Sunday at the Catholic church

‘A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10
‘a.m. Monday at the church.

‘Burial will be in the Catholic section of Lone Moun:
tain Cemetery

Walton's Chapel of the Valley is in charge of
arrangements,

‘A memorial is being established with the Corpus
Christi Catholic Church Building Fund, P.O, Box #24,

City, 89702.
vision:
1. PEOPLE:
   - James Monyak
2. DATES:
   - September 17, 1946 (date of birth)
3. PLACES:
   - Reno, a native Villanova in Pennsylvania (place where he was born), and moved to Carlisle Township, Cambria County four years after his birth.
   - Dayton: spent the last year of WWII there as an Army soldier
   - 1946-50; worked at GM, Detroit Michigan
   - Member for two terms in Pennsylvania House from 2nd district (specific time period not mentioned)
   - Cleveland Christ Church member and served on board.
   - Current residence: Dayton
   - Currently resides with his widow Marie Ann Monyak

4. DOCUMENT TYPE:
5. DESCRIPTION:
This image shows a newspaper obituary for James Monyak, who passed away at the age of 66 in Dayton from pancreatic cancer while staying in Reno hospital. It provides details about his early life and military service during WWII before settling down as an Army soldier until he retired with GM (General Motors). He was also mentioned to have been a member of Pennsylvania House for two terms, served on board at Cleveland Christ Church, is survived by his wife Marie Ann Monyak along with their three children. The document includes information about the memorial service and other personal details like places where lived before passing away.

filename: 0110_Gower Cemetery in Sciota, Pennsylvania - Find A Grave Cemetery (1)_79a2f344.png
title: Gower Cemetery in Sciota, Pennsylvania - Find A Grave Cemetery (1)
ocr_text:
Aka. Altemose's Church, Butts/Butz Run. Located south of
Sciota on the edge of the Blue Mountain Golf Course. From
Sciota, drive south toward Saylorsburg. About 6/10 of a mile
past the Township School, turn left in the Golf Course
entrance road. The cemetery is on the left about 1/10 of a
mile. The earliest tombstone here is that of Schalotta
Altemus, who died in 1806, wife of Nicholas. The last burial
took place in 1914. Families buried here are Altemus, Barrier,
Fleyt, Gower, Lessig, Meixell, Remel, Sandt, Shafer, and
Werkheiser. This burial ground is well maintained even
though not in use for many years. There was a church here at
one time but it has been gone for many years. (Extracted from
page 8 of "Guide to Cemeteries and Burial Grounds of Monroe
County, Pennsylvania", compiled by Dale E. Berger, January,
1995, First Edition)

   - Nicholas Altlemus's wife (date of death not specified in this document)

   - Saylorsburg, Pennsylvania
   - Monroe County, Pennsylvania

4. DOCUMENT TYPE: The text is an extract from a published source titled "Guide to Cemeteries and Burial Grounds of Monroe County, Pennsylvania," compiled by Dale E. Berger.

5. DESCRIPTION:
The document describes the location and historical significance of Alttemose's Church Cemetery in Scolota Township, Monroe County, Pennsylvania. It provides directions for visiting the cemetery from Saylorsburg to Scholota on a golf course road, mentions some early burials including that of Nicholas Altlemus' wife (died 1806), and notes other families buried there over time such as Altemus, Barrier, Fleyt, Gower, Lessig, Meixell, Remel, Sandt, Shafer, Werkheiser. It also discusses the current state of the cemetery grounds which are maintained but not used regularly due to a church's lack of use for many years.

The image appears as text from a printed or published source rather than an actual photograph or any other type listed in the document types section.

title: William Lawrence Neidrick b 1913 obit from The Progress, 30 Oct 1996 pg 19
ocr_text:
William L. Neldrick

PHILIPSBURG — William
Lawrence Neldrick, 83, of 502
12th St., Philipsburg, died at 4:35
p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 29, 1996, at his
residence,

Born July 9, 1913, in Osceola
Mills, he was a son of the late
William Fredrick and Hannah
(Brownhill) Neidrick.

Mr, Neidrick was of the
Episcopal Faith and was a
member of the IBEW Local 126,

On July 14, 1941, in Philips-
burg, he married the former
Alma Ruth Frye, who survives,

In addition to his wife, he is
survived by a daughter, Mar-
garet Ann Hoover; two sons,
William Robert and Gary Albert,
all of Philipsburg; six grand-
children and three sisters, Edith
Perry of Costa Mesa, Calif.,
Anna Mary Seyler of Mill Hall
and Margaret Welker of Bigler,

In addition to his parents, Mr.
Neidrick was preceded in death
by a granddaughter, Sonia Lee
Green; two sisters, Ella Ruth
Mason and Ethel Neidrick; and
three brothers, Albevt, Fredrick
and Arthur.

Private services will be held at
the convenience of the family at
the David K. Dahlgren Funeral
Home in Philipsburg with the
Rev. James R. Behrens of-
ficiating.

Interment will be in Philips-
burg Cemetery.

The family suggests memorial
contributions be made to the
Circle of Friends, Clearfield
Foundation for Care, Hospice,
220 Presqueisle St., Philipsburg,
Pa. 16866.

LK tet pace Metone,

title: Catharine Cadigan (Burke) Obituary
ocr_text:
AIGOMA RECORD, Friday, March 1, 1912: Demise of Pioneers - Mrs. Michael Burke, of
Casco, Also Goes To Great Beyond - Mrs. Michael Burke

Once again we are called upon to chronicle the departure of another one of the pioneer
residents of Casco, into the "Great Beyond," that of Mrs. Michael Burke, who passed
away at her home in the village of Casco, on Wednesday evening February 21, after an
illness of nearly five months duration.

Mrrs. Burke whose maiden name was Catharine Cadigan, was born in County Cork,
Ireland, in the year 1835 and emigrated to Canada about the year 1850 after spending a
few years there she went to Buffalo, New York, where in November, 1857 she was
united in marriage to Michael Burke, who preceded her to the grave in October, 1905.

In the month of October, 1860, Mr. and Mrs. Burke came to Casco and purchased the
farm which now belongs to their son, D. J. Burke. Here they lived until October, 1865,
when they went to Peterbourough, Canada, living there a year, and returning to Casco
in the fall of 1866, going back to the "Old Homestead" which was their home until 1902,
when they moved to the village of Casco

Mrs. Burke was known as a faithful, industrious, kind hearted, hard working woman who
was always ready to lend a helping hand.

She was a member of the Holy Rosary Society of the Holy Trinity Church the members
of which attended the funeral in a body to pay a last tribute to the deceased

Among those from outside who were present at the funeral were: son D. W. Burke, her
grandchildren Katy M. Burke and Mary E. Burke, of Milwaukee; William D. Burke, of
Kewaskum; also Mrs. C. J. Burke, of Marinette; Mrs. E. J. Kelliher, of Luxemburg; Mr.
and Mrs. Michael Shea, Green Bay; Mrs. P. Kashek and the Misses Lena Melchior and
Sophia Welniak, of Algoma, and Mr. and Mrs. John Murphy, of Kewaunee.

Left to mourn her loss are four sons and one daughter, namely: M. W. Burke, of Casco;
D. W. Burke, of Chicago; Mrs. Thos. McCalvey, Casco; D. J. Burke, and P. F. Burke of
Casco, also seventeen grandchildren and one brother.

The funeral was held from Holy Trinity Church at Casco, Saturday at 10 o'clock, Rev. E.
Kabat officiating, and was largely attended by friends and relatives

title: John Woodling of Germany
ocr_text:
A Biographical History and Genealogy of the WOODLING FAMILY
by Dr. Charles A Fisher, Historian and Genealogist

Selinsgrove, Pennsylvania, 1936

929.2, W859f, Oregon State Library

The Woodling Family
The Name is found in public records as Woodly, Woodley, Wodly, Wodley, Woodle, Wutling, Wutly, etc. The
most common use today is Woodling.

The European Home of the family is believed to have been Germany, although there are some who claim that
the family is of English origin. One indication against this belief is that all the pioneer members of the family
wrote and spoke German.

[pg 3]

1---John Woodling
John Woodling seems to have been the first of the family to live in this country. In 1774 he lived in Northern
Liberties Township, Philadelphia County, Pa., and in 1782 in Frederick Twp., same county. This later became
Frederick Township of Montgomery County. He must have been an old man at the time, because no record is
available showing his service in the Revolution. It is believed that his sons were: Andrew, Mathias, David,
John George, Samuel, and John.

title: Mahoning Presbyterian Chruch history
ocr_text:
MAHONING CONGREGATION OF THE UNITED PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH
LOCATED IN EAST MAHONING TOWNSHIP.

Mahoning congregation was first occupied as a preaching station in 1809, and continued as such about
nineteen years. In 1828 it was organized as a congregation, and fir first officers elected, namely, William
McCreery and Hugh Hamilton.

Fifty members entered the new organization whose names are as follows: William McCreeyy,
Margaret McCreery, Jane McCreery, Margaret McCreery, S. F. McCreery, John Hopkins, Margaret
Hopkins, Rosanna Hopkins, Robert Hopkins, Robert Hamilton, Jane Hamilton, Robert Hamilton, jr.,
Rachel Hamilton, Hugh Hamilton, Nancy Hamilton, Miriam Work, Aaron Work, Mary Work, Miriam
Work, James Work. Mary Work, A. S. Work, Margaret Work, John Work, Martha Work, William Work,
Robert Lytle, Catharine Lytle, William Lytle, John Lytle, Elizabeth Lytle, Sarah Lytle, James Mabon,
Matthew Steel, Sarah Steel, Robert Craig, Agnes Craig, Samuel Simpson, Phoebe Simpson, Andrew
Gibson and wife, John Thompson, Jane Thompson, John Coon, Nancy Coon, Nancy Smith, Martha
Hopkins, Margaret Hopkins.

The officers elected since the first organization who are not now in the congregation are: Robert Lytle,
A. S. Work, John Trimble, John Ewing, and Aaron Work. The present officers are: James McCreery,
Robert McCreery, William Hamil, John Clyde and Abner Briggs.

Rev. John Hindman took pastoral charge of the congregation in 1830 and continued until 1849. In
January, 1850, Rev. J. C. Telford took charge of the congregation and labored as pastor until April, 1867.
Rev. D. M. Thorn became pastor October 16, 1868, and continued as pastor between one and two years.
Rev. D. W. McLane began pastoral labor the 1* of March, 1871, and remained four years. Rev. D. H.
Blair, the present pastor, began labor the 1* of August, 1877.

The first church building was erected in 1833 on the ground now occupied by the church. The
building cost about $700. The present edifice was erected in 1857 at a cost of about $1,800.

One young man from this congregation entered the ministry, namely, William H. McCreery, now
laboring as a missionary in Loveland, Colorado.
vision:
This genealogy document appears to be a historical account of the Mahoning Presbyterian Church located in East Mahoning Township. It outlines significant milestones such as its establishment as a preaching station around 1809 and recognized congregation status from 1828.

- Robert Hopkins, Rosanna Hopkins, Nancy McCreery,
- Ralph Hamilton, Hugh Hamilton, Mary Work, Aarom Wood, James McCreery (father)
- Robert Lytle
- John Trimble, Albert Ewing, Aaron Works

DATES:

2. Recognized congregation status since 1828.

title: Obituary
ocr_text:
MELLOTT - Jessie L., 74, Turner
Apartments, Ebensburg, formerly
of Mundys Corner, went to be with
the Lord April 14, 1999, at Lee Hospi-
tal. Born July 26, 1924, in Buffington
Township, daughter of Clair and
Catherine (Frye) Brown. Preceded
in death by father; husband,
Lorenzo W. Mellott; and grandson,
Tommy Williams. Survived by
mother, Ebensburg; and these chil-
dren: Diana E., wife of John
Mikolic, Hanna, Wyo.; Curtis R.,
married to former Diane Reese,
Kendall Park, N.J.; Kevin J., mar-
ried to former Lillian Bates, Cham-
bersburg; and Cathy L., wife of
Kenneth Williams, Vinco; also 11
grandchildren and three great-
grandchildren. Sister of Ronald
Brown, Vintondale; Rosella Lack,
Benzonia, Mich.; Leora Crawford,
Nanty Glo R.D.; Shirley Anderson,
Gap; Marjorie Zarnesky and Cather-
ine Woodling, both of Ebensburg
R.D.; Joyce Eckenrode and Betty
Anderson, both of Florida; and
Paulette Bracken, Barnesboro R.D.
Member of Singer Hill Grace Breth-
ren Church, Vinco. Retired, she had
been employed over the years as a
cook and as an Avon Lady. Friends
will be received from 2 to 4 and 7 to
9 p.m. Thursday at Askew-Houser
Funeral Homes Inc., Nanty Glo,
where a funeral service will be held
at 11 a.m. Friday, the Rev. Ronald P.
Carnevalli officiating. Interment,
Pike Brethren Cemetery, Mundys
Corner.

vision:
1. PEOPLE:
   - Margaret Galbraith
   - Duncan Mylchhinchik or Shaw Dowler on May 28th/1791 in Galtreath.
   - Alexander son to John Galbrighton.
   - Margaret Gaibright daughter(s) of the Island of Stoney and Islay Mary 6 days before June
   - Malcolm all Ghirdn in Newmullin, Colby on Stoney.
   - M.William laugherer to the deceased Robert H. Mitchell late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd the 28th,
     married May 5th of June with wife John Hemwer
   - Jane Steel daughter to the deceased Hugh Steel in his parish or Kintail on the 18th day of June.
   - Margaret Galbraith, mother all Ghirdnall and Islay Mary (the second Mrs. Robert H.). She married the late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd the same
     date as Alexander son to John Gaibrighton,
   - William Hemwer in Anthosay on May 28th.
   - Magdaline Hemwer all Ghirdnall and Islay Mary (the second Mrs. Robert H.). She married the late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd
     with his wife Margaret Galbraith, mother to John Gaibrighton,
   - Hugh Steel daughter in Kintail on 18 June.
   - Robert Hemwer too all Ghirdnall and Islay Mary (the second Mrs. Robert H.). She married the late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd
     with her husband Christian Brown his wife, to whom he was married before July or after December of that year,
     who lived in Anthosay on 18 June.
   - M.D. Galbraith (Margaret Hemwer) daughter all Ghirdnall and Islay Mary (the second Mrs. Robert H.). She
     married the late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd, with her husband Christian Brown,
   - John Mylchhinchik Boatman to son decauses Adam in September.
   - Margaret Hemwer died 25th March all Ghirdnall and Islay Mary (the second Mrs. Robert H.). She married the late Miller at Glenburnie Bootherd
     with her husband Christian Brown,
   - William Hemwed on August 1879, son to John Hemwed.

   - May 24th/1790 in Galtreath.

Dear Cousin,

Ennismore Dec. 13, 18684

I now take the pleasure of yriting to these few lines i
to find you in as good health as this leaves us at present, tae
God. Well we got home safe and I was so busy since I came home
I had no time to write but I hope you will excuse me for not writ—
ing sooner. John and family are well and Mary ann and family are
weli. There is no snox or frost here yet and people could pior
if they had a mind to. prices are very low:

wheat fall 68% to 70¢
wheat spring 68 8 2
barley 56 *

peas — , 58 8 62

cats GAC joo 2
potatoes (bag 35% fis
apples O.= . 7%

veef (per 100 1bs.$4.50 to $5.50
pork " $6.09 to $7.00
butter (1b. 20 te 8?

I would like if you would let me know how the mare is that
got kicked or have you got your black stallion yet and I would
like to know if you got your Canditate in and I hope Cristy and
wife and family are well and I will write toe them in a few days.
I forgot getting your picture when I was over and I hope you will
send yours and dv the woman's when you write.

After we left you we went to Grun Bay then to New London then
to Ryelton. We saw a great many of old neighbors that we did not
see in 28 years and found them all well and doing well. Then we
went to Milwaukee then we crossed over on the boat to Grand Haven
then to Miskegon we stomped there 2 days at our coasin Lizzie
McDonald then we to a bee line home to Pidgson Creek. If I thought
they were getting along so well at home I would likely etay longer
the next time I go I will stay longer. I wish you well be up to
your word and you and the Mrs. come over next fall. Write soon:

Thomas Flood
Ennismore F.Q. Ontario.

title: IMG_1342
ocr_text:
running water in the kitchen, they had no bathrooms so used a bucket or an

outhouse.
The family moved to Flat Rock, Michigan in 1955, where George found work as
a bricklayer in a steel mill. Then their second son, Thomas Edward Lack was

added to the family.

George built their Van Horn Rd. home in Flat Rock. Rose too helped with

building the home. We often heard of how Rose, (who was afraid of heights) tied
herself to the chimney, in case she fell while putting shingles on the roof. She
carried block., mud, and brick, working as hard as any man.

Rose was the quintessential housewife of the 1940's and 50’s. Cooking, cleaning,
and mother to Butch and Tom, two very rambunctious boys.

In later years Butch and Tom often reminded Rose how she would use anything
in her hand at the time when disciplining. They recount, their mother throwing
a shoe, hitting them both with one throw, (2 birds with one stone).

The family was very involved with their church Evangel Baptist in Taylor,

Michigan. Attending services Sunday mornings, Sunday evenings, and
Wednesday evenings. They made many lifetime friends with families from the
church.

Rose taught Sunday School to preschool and kindergarten children for over 50
years (at Evangel Baptist, then at Herring Lake Baptist Church). She taught
hundreds of children over the years, including her own children, and her
grandchildren. She also had a neighborhood bible study for the children on

their road in Flat Rock.

When George retired they built another home on 5 acres on Arner Ra. in
Benzonia, Michigan. They enjoyed gardening, fishing, and hunting. Rose began
deer hunting at the age of 60 years and loved it. She had her own dear blind

Rese

Rose was born on October 13, 1926, to Catherine Louise Fry and Clair Everett

Brown at home in Vinco, Pennsylvania. She was the second of 10 children. Her
older sister was Jessie Lois Mellot (Lorenzo) who proceeded her in death in 1999.
Her younger siblings are Leora Maude Crawford (Kenneth), Shirley Mae
Anderson (Irvin-Chub), Betty June (Cole), Marjorie Claire Zarnesky (Blair),
Ronald James Brown (Jean), Catherine Alvira ‘Woodling (Lynn), Joyce Romaitiie
Eckenrode (Clint), Paulette Sue Bracken (Dave).

Rose and her siblings were raised in rural Pennsylvania, a family of modest
means, where Rose recalled the family camping and swimming, fishing with

her father, and running and jumping. She said she could run faster and jump
higher than any boy. Rose did not like school and in the 6" grade, quit school to
help at home. She often recounted taking care of her siblings, baby after baby,
helping with all aspects of their care including disciplining, her responsibilities
were well beyond the expectations of an eleven-year-old. Rose eventually
worked outside of the house, at a dry cleaner and in a sewing factory doing

piecework.

On May 2, 1947, Rose married George Lack, the son of Russian immigrants who
had settled in Ebensburg, Pennsylvania. Rose worked hard as a homemaker,
while George worked in the steel mill. Their son George L. Lack (Butch), was
born on August 11, 1949. The family first lived in an apartment above a barn at

the Lack family farm in Ebensburg, Pennsylvania, and although they had

title: IMG_1222
ocr_text:
!
,

Helen T. Turanik Lack

BIRTH 9 Apr 1919
DEATH 31 Mar 2016 (aged 96)
BURIAL Grandview Cemetery
Southmont, Cambria County, Pennsylvania, USA
PLOT Overbrook 1, Lot 130

MEMORIAL iD 163736281

LACK - Helen T., 96, Dale City, Va., formerly of East Conemaugh, passed
away March 31, 2016, at her daughter's residence. She was born April 9,
1919, in East Conemaugh, daughter of Michael and Mary (Baloga)
Turanik. In addition to her parents, she is preceded in death by her
husband, John; sisters, Anna, Verna, Julia and Mary; and brothers,
George, Charles, John and Michael. She is survived by her loving
children, Kathleen M., wife of John Smoter, Johnstown; JoAnn L.
Chavez, Dale City, Va.; andMary Ann, wife of Carlos A. Hernandez,
Richmond, Va.; grandchildren, Michele and John Paul Smoter and John
Carlos Hernandez; and several nieces and nephews. Helen was a 1938
graduate of Conemaugh High School. She was a member of Holy Trinity
Byzantine Catholic Church, East Conemaugh. Helen enjoyed singing
carols with family and friends at holiday time. She also loved cooking,
baking, knitting and crocheting, and will be remembered as a loving,
giving and kind mother, sister, grandmother and friend. Viewing will be
held from 3 to 7 p.m. Sunday, April 3, at the Baker-Harris Funeral
Chapel, Conemaugh. An additional viewing will id from 9 a.m.
until time of Parastas at 10 a.m, Monday, April 4, atthe funeral home,
with the Rev. Dr. Robert F. Oravetz. Committal will be held at Grandview
Cemetery. Online condolences may be posted to

Johnstown Tribune-Democrat
April 2, 2016

William L, Neldrick

PHILIPSBURG —- William
Lawrence Neidrick, 83, of 502
12th St., Philipsburg, died at 4:35
p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 29, 1996, at his.
residence,

Born July 9, 1913, in Osceola
Mills, he was a son of the late
William Fredrick and Hannah
(Brownhill) Neidrick.

Mr. Neidrick was of the
Episcopal Faith and was a
member of the IBEW Local 126,

On July 14, 1941, in Philips-
burg, he married the former
Alma Ruth Frye, who survives,

In addition to his wife, he is
survived by a daughter, Mar-
garet Ann Hoover; two sons,
William Robert and Gary Albert,
all of Philipsburg; six grand-
children and three sisters, Edith
Perry of Costa Mesa, Calif.,
Anna Mary Seyler of Mill Hall
and Margaret Welker of Bigler,

In addition to his parents, Mr.
Neidrick was preceded in death
by a granddaughter, Sonia Lee
Green; two sisters, Ella Ruth
Mason and Ethel Neidrick; and
three brothers, Albevt, Fredrick
and Arthur.

Private services will be held at
the convenience of the family at
the David K. Dahlgren Funeral
Home in Philipsburg with the
Rev. James R. Behrens of-
ficiating.

Interment will be in Philips-
burg Cemetery.

The family suggests memorial
contributions be made to the
Circle of Friends, Clearfield
Foundation for Care, Hospice,
220 Presqueisle St., Philipsburg,
Pa, 16866.

day Inn and Sheraton, both of

Edith P.Frye _

September 3, 1922 — May 18, 2006

Edith P. Frye, 83, formerly
of Port Matilda, died Thurs-
day, May 18, 2006, at the
home of her daughter, Glo-
ria, in State College.

She was born Sept. 3, 1922,
in Womelsdorf, a daughter of
Walter C. and Clara Belle __
(Ammerman) Crownover.

On Aug. 29, 1938, in Mary-
land, she married George E.
Frye. He died Feb. 1, 1994.

Surviving are two daugh-
ters, Gloria J. Pighetti, of
State College, and Beverly A.
Meek, of Port Matilda; two
sons, Edward G. and wife,
Patty, of Huntingdon, and
Leroy W. and wife, Jane, of
Port Matilda; 14 grandchil-
dren; 35 great-grandchildren;
three great-great-grandchil-
dren; and two sisters, Kather-
ine Harpster, a resident of
Tyrone Colonial Courtyard,
and Alice Rodgers, of Tyrone.

She was preceded in
death by a sister, Margaret
Kyper Williams; two broth-
ers, James and William
Crownover; and step-father,
George Sunday.

Mrs. Frye retired in 2000

from Wal-Mart, State College,
as a cashier, following 10
years service. She was previ-
ously employed at Renais-
sance Assisted Living, State
College; Eaken Rest Home,
Bald Eagle; and was a wait-
ress at Holiday Inn and Sher-
aton, both of State College.

She was a member of the
Port Matilda American Legion
Auxiliary and the Bellefonte
VFW Auxiliary. She was of
the Methodist faith.

Edith enjoyed bowling,
camping and animals.

Funeral services will be
held Monday, May 22, 2006,
at 2 p.m., at Feller Memorial
Home, 817 W. 15th St.,
Tyrone, with the Rev. Patri-
cia Gable officiating.

Interment will follow at Port
Matilda Presbyterian Ceme-
tery.

Friends will be received at
the funeral home on Sunday,
May 21, 2006, from 7 to 9 p.m.

Memorial gifts may be made
to Centre HomeCare and Hos-
pice, 2437 E. College Ave.,
State College, PA 16801.

title: Brockway9
ocr_text:
2008] Wolston Brockway of Lyme, Connecticut 43

stepson Joseph Hand “of Lyme” was “Impowered by [his] Mother Allic Codner”
to look after part of his estate. Concurrently, “Woolston Brockwaye was pre-
sented... in court for several misdemeanors and gave bond. But [he] has not
attended his bond but instead broke into the house of Edward Codner and robbed
it.” The court ordered Wolston’s “estate [be] attached to the value of 14 pounds.”
‘Then, “for breaking into Edward Codner’s house of Saybrooke and stealing from
a chest, Woollston Brockway [vas judged] notoriously guilty and sentenced to be
whipped on the naked body." There is no indication in all this what Wolston
took from Codner’s chest — or why — or that it had any lasting effect on his
standing in the community.
Next year, in August 1671, Wolston’s name appears with those of fifteen
Lyme inhabitants involved in the New London and Lyme “riot,” a controversy
about a two-mile-wide strip between Bride Brook and Niantic River, including
Black Point. ‘Those named included his uncle, Lt. William Waller. Those on the
other (New London) side included George Chappell of Wethersfield and New
London.'! George’s son John, however, resided in Lyme and had been an owner
of land adjoining property that Wolston conveyed in February 1679/80 to hi
“father William Briggs of Lyme.” John Chappell’s daughter Experience married
Robert Harris at Wethersfield in 1700, son of the sawmiller Thomas Harris,
probable brother-in-law of Wolston’s wife Hannah. Similar notice is taken of a
grant to Brockway in 1687 of land near “12 mile Island Cove,” where Thomas
probably had married Capt. Richard Wright’s daughter Sarah in about 1664."

New London County Court Records, Trials, 3:15, 16, 20. I thank Norman W. Ingham, co,
for calling my attention to this curious matter and for providing extracts taken “mostly from the
‘original volumes & files” in 1992-93, The dates are in 1670, but Ingham points out that some
specific dates of early sessions on this volume are hard to discem “due to its fragmentary
condition.”

J, Hammond Trumbull, The Public Records of the Colony of Connecticut, 15 vols.
(Hartford, Conn: Case, Lockwood & Brainard, 1850-90), 2:558. Regarding this affair, Wolston
deposed in March 1671/2: “This deponent witnesseth that as the constable of Lyme was
apprehending Clement Minor at black point, Peter Stickling [Strickland] of New London as wee
are informed hee is Called came amongst the company with his sithe, and being desired by
Woolstan Brockway to Lay down his Sythe Least he should do some mischiefe with it: the said
Stickling answered’s wounds [sie] I will run it in to your heart iting up his sythe as ifhe would
have cut him down: but Woolstan clapt in upon him and prevented him: who notwithstanding
gzather’d up his sythe close to Woolstan greatly endangering the cutting of his neck and body untill
itwas wrenched out of his hands.” (Conneticut Archives, Towns and Lands, 114, as transcribed
in Smith and Sanborn, Ancestry of Emily Jane Angell (note 1, 04.) See also Ullmann, Hartford
‘County Court Minutes (note 27), 153

* Gale lon Harris, “Robert Harris of Connecticut and Descendants in the Hudson Valley,”
The New York Genealogical and Biographical Record 130 (1999):183-88, On 31 December 1677,
John Chappel and Wolston Brockway were chosen as Lyme’s fence viewers “for the year
‘ensueing” (Bur, Lyme Records [note $5], 29).

Lyme Deeds, 1:82; G:29; Harris, “Captain Richard Wright” [note 49], The American
Genealogist 67:33

title: Brockway1
ocr_text:
WOLSTON! BROCK WAY OF LYME, CONNECTICUT
With Further Analysis of His Associations

Gale Ion Harris

Dean Crawford Smith and Melinde Lutz Sanborn have identified Wolston
Brockway’s parents and clarified his maternal ancestry. He was a son of William*
and Bridget (Waller) Brockway of Norwich, Norfolk, who were married at Saint
Giles Without Cripplegate in London on 28 January 1628/9. His mother was a
sister of Matthew Waller of New London and William Waller of Lyme, Connee-
ticut. Also, she was a niece of Gregory’ Wolterton (1593-1674) of Wethersfield
and Hartford, Connecticut, whose sister Sarah had married Thomas Waller."'! As
noted by Smith and Sanborn, on 3 December 1657 John Winthrop Jr. at Hartford
mentioned “Waller, the wido: 74 years old at G: Wooltertone she is his sister & is
Math: Waller’s mother.”"! Therefore, Wolston Brockway’s maternal grandparents
were Thomas Waller and his wife Sarah Wolterton."! The absence of Wolston’s
parents or any identified siblings in New England records suggests that he came
to America with his grandmother Sarah (Wolterton) Waller and, asa child,
probably lived with her at Hartford.

The objective of the present article is to further examine Wolston’s career in
New England with particular attention to his marriages. immediate family, and
associations. My interest in this Lyme settler was aroused many years ago by his
conspicuous but still largely unexplained tendency to be associated in various
ways with Harrises, whose relationships to each other generally remain difficult to
pin down, For example, he had both a stepson John Harris and a son-in-law
William Harris, and it is not known how they might have been related. ‘The focus
here, however, is on Wolston Brockway and readers are referred in the following
ages to discussions elsewhere of the various Harris puzzles encountered

Other work has confirmed that Hannah, the mother of all of Wolston’s
children (born 1664-1685), was William Briggs’s daughter Hannah, born at
Boston in 1642." William Briggs came to Lyme and referred to Wolston in

“Dean Crawford Smith, The Ancestry of Emily Jane Angell, 1844-1910, Melinde Lutz

authors with Robert Charles Anderson, “The English Woltertons: Ancestors of the Waller and
Brockway Families of Connecticut,” The American Genealogist 68 (1993) 160-75,

title: Brockway7
ocr_text:
2008] Wolston Brockway of Lyme, Connecticut B

the lands there to prospective settlers." One of those settlers by 1664 was
William Harris, whose son William married Wolston’s daughter Elizabeth
Brockway at Block Island in 1697.7)

As yet another indication of the associations involved, John and ‘Thomas
Whitehead’s mother had conveyed her concem about them in a letter to her
brother Thomas Alcock of Boston, dated at Leamington Priors in 1647. stating
that Richard Wright had visited but could give her no news of them."*! In the
mid-1660s, Richard Wright, then styled “Capt. Wright,” apparently was in the
middle of a four-year lease of the farm called 7welve-Mile Island located on the
east side of the Connecticut River by Wolston’s land and at the boundary between
Saybrook and Thirty-Mile Island (Soon to become the boundary between Lyme
and East Haddam)."! In September 1661, the Twelve-Mile-Island farm had
passed from its original grantee, Capt. John Cullick, to Capt, John Leverett of
Boston.) Lyme records show that Leverett, later Governor of Massachusetts,
leased it to a succession of tenants, each for four-year terms.) In 1663 or 1664,
midterm in Leverett’s lease to Captain Wright, John Harris's apparent brother
‘Thomas married Wright’s daughter Sarah. After the lease expired in 1666,
Wright, with his daughter and her Harris husband in tow, moved to Podunk in the
north part of (modern) East Hartford to run a sawmill.*! Thomas Harris’s land at
Podunk adjoined William Buckland, brother-in-law of William’ Biggs/Briggs of
Middletown, nephew of Hannah (Briggs) (Harris) Brockway."

To summarize, while not temporarily employed elsewhere Wolston probably
resided for several years before 1664 in Wethersfield, where his. great-uncle
Gregory Wolterton owned property, and near the place where his wife Hannah's
parents resided from 1665 to 1670. Hannah probably had preceded them to
Wethersfield (the part of it that became Glastonbury) as early as March 1659/60
with her first husband, John Harris, their infant son John Harris bom at Boston in
August 1658," and her stepsons Walter Harris and Thomas Harris. Her husband

title: Brockway10
ocr_text:
46 New England Historical and Genealogical Register (JANUARY

On 14 January 1677/8, Wolston Brockway was listed as one of the thirty-six
proprietors of Lyme.! The schedule of taxes levied in Lyme in August 1688
includes Wolston’s household with “3 persons, house and lands,” and livestock,
all valued at £103!) In December 1699 Wolston yas “chosen constable for the
year ensueing, but refuses to serve as a constable.”"”! About 1700 his household
may have included his step-sranddaughter Sarah Harris trom Northampton or
Westfield, Massachusetts.

Wolston’s son Richard Brockway, who gave bond with John Wade as his
administrator on 5 November 1718, presented on 9 December 1718 an inventory
valued at £25 15s, Sd. and an account of his payments from the estate totaling £24
1s, 9d! No distribution was filed, presumably because so little was left after
debts were paid.

(to be continued)

title: Brockway3
ocr_text:
2008] Wolston Brockway of Lyme, Connecticut 39

Brockway Sr.— citing his “present old age and infirmities” — and “my wife
Hannah Brockway (y' now is)” conveyed their homestead at Lyme on 12 March
1707/8 to his son Richard Brockway. It is clear the scrivener intended to write
“Hannah,” not “Sarah.” Her mark, H, is indicated on the document as made by
“hanah Brockway.” and Wolston and “Hanah his wife” acknowledged next day
across the Connecticut River in Saybrook.'"* This record shows that in his old
age, Wolston married third, soon before 12 March 1707/8, another woman named
Hannah; whose sumame remains unknown.'"*! In May 1717 Wolston gave a
feather bed and other items to his daughter Hannah Wade, but reserved it to “my
now wife hanah” to use for life or until remarried.""! His wif Hannah — his
second of that name — died perhaps soon afterward, as she is not mentioned in
the probate of his estate at Lyme, where he died on 14 September 1718.!"7)

‘THE EARLIER CAREER OF WOLSTON BROCKWAY.

Wolston testified on 10 July 1714 that he was aged “70 years or thereabouts,
and had dwelt in Lyme “for 50 years past.""'"! He probably understated his age.
for in December 1659 he was old enough to buy a house and land in Lyme (then
part of Saybrook).""?! Thus, an estimate of his birth date as “not far from 1638")
(rather than about 1644) seems likely.

Before 1651 Wolston’s great-uncle Gregory Wolterton owned land in Hoc-
kanum (south end of modem East Hartford near the Glastonbury town line). By
1663 he owned other nearby property several rods south of land on Pewter Pott
Brook owned later by Thomas Harris, a sawmiller and likely but unproven brother
of John Harris, the prior husband of Wolston’s first wife Hannah." In 1665
Gregory, a tanner, bought a homestead in Wethersfield, which he sold to Samuel

8 Lyme Deeds, 2:370.

One may wonder whether the bride's given name, Sarah, in the 1705 marriage record at
Boston might be a mistake or a mistranscription of Hanah. Although this remains possible, the
circumstances strongly indicate that she was the widow of John’ Briggs, whose name is otherwise
known as Sarah,

"The entry in Clarence Almon Torey, New England Marriages Prior to 1700, CD-ROM
(Boston: NEHGS, 2001), showing that Wolston had a second wife Hannah with sumame Briges,
possibly results from some confusion with his first wife. The statement isnot supported by the sources
cited for Torrey’s entry or by any evidence found in the present work

1680/1 as “my sonne.”! Regarding this, in 1960 Donald Lines Jacobus men-
tioned some “doubts” communicated to him by Roderick Bissell Jones, which ap-
parently were directed at Jacobus’s statement in 1957 that Hannah was the
“svidow of John Harris of Lyme."*! She was indeed the widow of a John Harris
when she married Wolston Brockway. Any error in Jacobus’s statement narrows
to whether Hannah’s prior husband, John Harris, was ever “of Lyme.” That has
not been confirmed; circumstances reviewed in the present article suggest that
Hannah and Wolston were married in or near Glastonbury (then part of Weth-
ersfield), probably where her husband John Harris had died, not in Lyme where
early records of a John Harris Pe instead to John Harris [son of John and
Hannah], born at Boston in 1658. T Some, but not all, of Brockway’s later Harris
associations may be understood if, as shown elsewhere to be probable.) his
young first wife, Hannah, had stepsons Walter Harris and Thomas Harris from a
Prior, unrecorded marriage of her husband John Harri

Wolston’s marriages are confusing. He had at least three wives, two of them
from Boston and two named Hannah. By September 1664 (birth of first child) he
had married Hannah (Briggs) Harris, born at Boston on 28 August 1642, daughter
of William! and Mary (___) Briggs who moved from Boston to Middletown,
Connecticut, in 1665, then on to Lyme in 1670.0) Hannah died as “goodwife
Brockway” at Lyme on 6 February 1687[/8}.""! Wolston apparently remained a
widower for the better part of two decades, all the while staying in close contact
with his deceased wife’s relatives. Surely he (not his son of the same name) was
the “Wooliston Brockway” who married at Boston’s Old South Church on 29
November 1705, Sarah Briggs! [the widow of his first wife's brother, John?
Briggs of Lyme and Boston"?! 4 subsequent record, however, further tends 10
confiuse. Twenty-eight months after marrying Sarah Briggs in Boston, Wolston

title: Death - Brockway, Margaret (Tilley)
ocr_text:
Obituaries

Margaret Brockway

Mrs. Margaret L. Brockway of 81 Eugene St., died May
30 at Zephyr Haven Nursing Home. She was 82.

Born Dec. 30, 1899, in London, Ky., she came to
Zephyrhills 14 years ago from Inkster, Mich., and was a
homemaker and 2 Presbyterian.

‘Survivors include her husband, Stanley T. of Zephyrhills;
two sons, Glenn L. of Phoenix, Ariz. and Theodore S. Jr. of
Dearborn, Mich.; 11 grandchildren; nine great-
grandchildren; and two brothers, James Tilley of Kent, Ind.
and Newton Tilley of Madison, Ind.

Funeral services were Tuesday at the chapel of Kelly
Funeral Home with the Rev. John Mackley officiating.
Cremation followed.

ocr_text:
IN MEMORY OF

Florence M. Erdman
BORN
May 11, 1907
DIED
December 7, 1999

The Lord is my shepherd I shall not want.
He maketh me to lie down in green pastures;
He leadeth me beside the still waters. He
restoreth my soul. He leadeth me in the path
of righteousness for His name's sake. Yea,
though I walk through the valley of the
shadow of death, I will fear no evil; for Thou
art with me; Thy rod and Thy staff they
comfort me. Thou preparest a table before me
in the presence of mine enemies. Thou
anointest my head with oil; my cup runneth
over. Surely goodness and mercy shall follow
me all the days of my life; and I will dwell in

the house of the Lord forever. Amen.

J.L. Peters Funeral Home inc.

t

In Loving Memory
Of

Florence M. Erdman

Whose Final Resting Place Is
Garden of the Holy Trinity

Section 678, Grave 02

title: Obituary for Hannah McMannmy

Mrs. Hannah McManamy, wife of
James A. McManamy, at 6.10 yester-
day morning, at the home of her
daughter, Mrs. M. H. Neaffer, of
2122 Highth avenue, of a complica-
tion of diseases. The maiden name
of the deceased was Hannah Corne-
linus. She was born at Tyrone Forg-
es, July 6, 1833. Besides her hus-
band she is survived by the follow-
ing children: Mrs. Ella Murphy of
Summerhill, A. W., of Tyrone,
George of Harrisburg, Mrs. Belle
Emerick and Mrs. Miriam Neaffer,
of this city. One sister, Mrs. Rebec-
ica Carnes, also survives. She was
ja member of the Simpson Methodist
church, The remains can be view-
led from 4 until 9 this afternoon.
Funeral services will be held at the;
house tomorrow afternoon at 2
jo'cloek, Interment in Rose _ Hill
emetery.

title: Obituary for Rachel Ella Murphy
ocr_text:
MRS. RACHEL ELLA MURPHY

Mrs. Rachel Ella Murphy, widow
of James H, Murphy, and former
residents of Bald Eagle, died at
her home at South Fork on Satur-
day afternoon,

Mrs. Murphy was a member of
the Ladies’ Auxiliary to the B. of
R, T. of Tyrone.

She is survived by these chil-
dren: Beman Murphy, Earl
Murphy, Harrisburg; Harry E.
Murphy, Tyrone; Newton Murphy,
South Fork; Terence Murphy,
Akron, Ohio; Mrs. Hannah Skelly,
Pitcairn, and Mrs. Dora M. Lytle,
of South Fork.

ocr_text:
Tyrone Daily Herald (Tyrone, Pennsylvania) « 01 May 1997, Thu

+ Page2 (i)

1 of 7 matches bye ethel frye

E. Frye
Formerly Employed At Big Yank

Mrs, Ethel E. Frye, 67, formerly
of 957 Pennsylvania Ave., Tyr-
one, died at 12:25 a.m, Thursday,
May 1, 1997, after a lengthy illness
at the home of her daughter, 1007
Jefferson Ave., Tyrone, where she
had resided since Sept, 1996.

She was born May 25, 1929 at Ir-
onville, a daughter of the late
George William and Ethel Irena
(Lear) Miller. She was married
July 25, 1970 at Port Matilda to
Paul L. Frye who survives her.

Also surviving is one daughter,
Donna D. Miller, Tyrone; four
brothers, Martin W., Tyrone, R.D.
5; Morris, Daniel L. and Donald
Miller, all of Tyrone; four sisters,
Darlene Wertz, Tyrone, R.D. 3;
Twila Bowser, Lois Russell and
Georgette Umholtz, all of Tyrone;
two granddaughters, Kelly and
Amy Millet, Tyrone; two step-
sons and one step-daughter; and
five step-grandchildren.

* She was a member of the New

Life Assembly of God Church,
Bellwood, and | the Tyrone V.F.W.
Auxiliary.

Mrs. Frye had been a machine
operator at Big Yank Corp., Tyt-
‘one, for 10 years and was last em-

loyed at the F & F Drycleaners,
yrone, for 10 years.

Funeral services will be held
Saturday, 11 a.m., at the Derman
Funeral Home, Inc., Tyrone, with
Pastor Richard Rightenour offi-
ciating. Interment will be at Blair
Memorial Park, Antis Township.

Friends will be received at the
Derman Funeral Home, Inc. on
Friday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m.

Contributions in her memo
may be offered to the New Life
Assembly of God Church, RR 7,
Box 640, Altoona, Pa. 16602 or to
the Blair County Unit of the
American Cancer Society, 1004 N.

Lr Street, Hollidaysburg, PA

title: Joyce S Vaughn b 1930 obit
ocr_text:
Tyrone Daily Herald (Tyrone, Pennsylvania) . 23 Nov 2002, Sat +

1 of 5 matches

S. Vaughn

Joyce S. Vaughn, 72, of 1508
Plaza Drive, State College, formerly
of Port Matilda, died Friday,
November 22, 2002 at Centre Com-
munity Hospital.

She was born September 25,

1930 in Fowler Hollow, the daugh-
ter of John C. and Eunice (Richards)
Vaughn.
A devoted mother, she is sur-
vived by two sons, Paul J. Frye and
wife Lois of Port Matilda and Nor-
man V. Frye and wife Alison of Salt
Lake City, Ut., a daughter Terri Ann
Kramer and husband Rick of Royal
Oak, Mi., three grandsons, a grand-
daughter, a greatgrandson, a great-
granddaughter, a nephew and a sis-
ter Beryl Cohen of Vailejo, Calif.
She was preceded in death by three
sisters,

Mrs. Vaughn retired from Nittany
Oil Company as Office Manager

DLarklexr

Page 2 (J

working out of the State College,
Bellwood and Philipsburg offices
where she made many friends. For
many years she was associated with
the maintenance and enlarging of
the Mount Pleasant Cemetery in
Fowler Hollow, Port Matilda. She
was a 1947 graduate of Port Matilda
High School and enjoyed cooking,
baking and sewing for her family
and friends.

Funeral services will be held
today, SaturdayNovember 23, 2002
at 2 p.m. at Feller Memorial Home
with Rev, Patricia Gable officiating.
Interment will be at Mt. Pleasant
Cemetery. Friends will be received
today at 12 noon until the time of
the services.

Memorial gifts may be made to
the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery Associa-
ton, C/O Lois Bailey, 401 Douglas
Drive, State College, Pa. 16803

title: Paul Lloyd Frye b 1922 obit
ocr_text:
Centre Daily Times (State College, Pennsyl

+ 22 Nov 2008, Sat + Page Ad

September 2, 1922 —November 20, 2008

Paul Lloyd Frye, 86, of
= Jyrone, died
hursday, Nov.
=== 20, 2008, at the
Altoona Hospi-
tal, from injuries of a truck
and pedestrian accident in
Tyrone.

He was born Sept. 2, 1922,
at Vail, Snyder Twp., Pa., a
son of James and Maude
(Sones) Frye.

He was twice married, first
to Joyce Vaughn, then to
Ethel E. Miller, both
deceased.

He is survived by sons Paul
J. Frye (Lois), of Port Matilda,
Norman V. Frye (Allison), of
Salt Lake City, Utah; and
aebaeh Terry Ann Kramer

Richard), of Royal Oak, Mich.
Se Con Wallace (Danny),
of Tyrone; six grandchildren;
four great-grandchildren; a
brother, Charles Frye, of
Youngstown, Ohio; several
nieces and nephews; and his
faithful dog, “Charlie.”

He was preceded in death
by four sisters and two broth-
ers.

He was a member of the
Port Matilda Methodist
Church.

He served in the U.S. Army
during W.W.II with the 1st
Cavalry Division in the South
Pacific and was awarded five
Bronze Stars and one Bronze
Arrowhead. He was a mem-
ber of the Tyrone V.F.W.
#4559, the Hookies Fire Co.
and the Port Matilda Ameri-
can Legion. He enjoyed play-
ing the guitar and the har-
monica.

He retired in Sept. 1987 as
Plant Operator at Warner Co.,
Pemberton, with 17 and a half
years of service, and previ-
ously in Food Service at Penn
State University for 12 anda
half years and at the McFieldy
Brick Co., Port Matilda.

Funeral services will be held
Monday, Nov. 24, 2008, at 11
a.m. at the Derman Funeral
Home, Inc., Tyrone, with Pastor
Robert Smith officiating. Inter-
ment with Military Honors will
follow at Blair Memorial Park.

Friends will be received at
the funeral home on Sunday
from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m.

Contributions in his memo-
ry may be given to the Cen-
tral Pa. Humane Society,

title: Alma Ruth Frye b 1920 obit
ocr_text:
Centre Daily Times (State College, Pennsyl

+ 23 Mar 2002, Sat + Page4

Alma Ruth Neidrick

Ima Ruth Neidrick, 82, of
hilipsburg died Thursday,
March 21, 2002, at home.

Born Jan. 21, 1920, in Tyrone,
she was a daughter of the late
James and Maude Sones Frye.
On June 14, 1941, in Philipsburg,
she married William Lawrence
Neidrick, who died Oct. 29,
1996.

She was a homemaker.

She was a Protestant.

She is survived by two sons,
William Robert Neidrick of rural
Philipsburg and Gary Albert
Neidrick of Philipsburg; a sister,
Libbie Holbert of Lewistown;
two brothers, Paul Frye of

Tyrone and Charles Frye; and
six grandchildren.

A daughter, Margaret Ann
Hoover; a granddaughter; two
sisters; and two brothers preced-
ed her in death.

There will be no public visita-
tion.

The funeral will be at 2 p.m.
Sunday at David K. Dahlgren
Funeral Home, 228 N. Centre
St., Philipsburg.

Burial will be in Philipsburg
Cemetery.

Memorial contributions may
be made to Calvary United
Methodist Church, P.O. Box 41,
West Decatur, PA 16878.

Alma Ruth Neidrick

Ima Ruth Neidrick, 82, of
hilipsburg died Thursday,
March 21, 2002, athome. ~

Born Jan. 21, 1920; in Tyrone,
she was a daughter of the late
James and Maude Sones Frye.
On June 14, 1941, in Philipsburg,
she married William Lawrence
Neidrick, who died Oct. 29,
1996.

She was a homemaker.

She was a Protestant.

She is survived by two sons,
William Robert Neidrick of rural
Philipsburg and Gary Albert
Neidrick of Philipsburg; a sister,
Libbie Holbert of Lewistown;
two brothers, Paul Frye of

: Tyrone and Charles Frye; and

six grandchildren,

A daughter, Margaret Ann
Hoover; a granddaughter; two
sisters; and two brothers preced-

-ed her in death.

There will be no public visita-
tion. «

The funeral will be at 2 p.m.
Sunday at David K. Dahlgren
Funeral Home, 228 N. Centre
St., Philipsburg. ~ :

Burial will be in Philipsburg
Cemetery.

Memorial contributions may
be made to Calvary United
Methodist Church, PO. Box 41,
West Decatur, PA 16878.

title: Robert James Frye b 1913 obit
ocr_text:
, Pennsyl... + 04 Mar 1984, Sun

Robert J. Frye

Robert J. Frye, 70, of 208 S. High
St., Port Matilda, died in Centre
Community Hospital, Saturday at
6:30 a.m.

Born in Tyrone on March 10,
1913, he was the son of James and
Maude V. Sones Frye. He married
Mabel Funk on Aug. 9, 1983, who
survives.

Also surviving are three sons:
Max R. of York, James D. of
Bedford, Arthur L. of Port Matilda;
one daughter, Anita F. Newman of
State College: three brothers:
George of Port Matilda, Paul of
‘Tyrone and Charles of Jackson-
ville, Fla.; four sisters: Catherine
Brown of Ebensburg, Elizabeth
Holbert of Lewistown, Margaret
Devlin of Mineral Point and Alma
Neidrick of Philipsburg; four
grandchildren; and two great-

Idren.

He was a truck driver and
former owner of the Bargain Barn
in Port Matilda. He was a member
‘of the United Methodist church of
Port Matilda and a life member of
the Port Matilda Fire Company.

Funeral services will be at the
United Methodist Chruch in Port
Matilda, Monday at 2 p.m., with
the Rev. Philip Sabas officiating.
Burial will follow in Presbyterian
Cemetery, Port Matilda

Memorial contributions can be
made to the Home Health Services
of Bellefonte,

Funeral arrangements are under
the directon of the Wetzler Home in
Bellefonte.

title: Paul V Belanger Death
ocr_text:
PAUL BELANGER

Paul Vincent Belanger, 31, of Gladwin, died Tuesday, July 6, in Detroit. Born in Detroit
on April 6, 1951, he came to Gladwin County 18 months ago from Detroit. He was a
member of the Sacred Heart Catholic Church.

Surviving are one daughter, Christine; one son, Paul; his parents, Stan and Margaret
Belanger of Gladwin; and 11 brothers and sisters.

Rites were held Friday, July 9, in Detroit. Deacon Stan Belanger and the Rev. Father
Joseph Castanier officiated and burial was in the Sacred Heart Cemetery, Gladwin.
Gladwin County Record dated 7-21/1982 Column - 3 Page - 2.

title: Margaret M Belanger Death
ocr_text:
Margaret Mary Belanger, 90
Detroit News, The (MI) - Wednesday, April 15, 2009

Belanger Margaret Mary age 90 of Gladwin died April 14, 2009. Beloved wife of the late
Stanley Belanger (d. 2007). Loving mother of Helen (Jim) McGuire, John Belanger,
Robert (Diane) Belanger, Francis Mandeville, Bernadette Belanger, Bernard (Linda)
Belanger, Annette Belanger, James (Brenda) Belanger, and Renee (Jim) Bosman.

Preceded in death by her children Thomas (Judy) Belanger, Joseph Belanger, Paul
Belanger and Theresa Belanger. Also survived by 30 grandchildren and numerous great
grandchildren and great great grandchildren. Sister of the late Richard and Owen
Flynn.

Funeral Mass from St. William Catholic Church, Walled Lake Thursday 12:30 p.m.
Interment Sacred Heart Cemetery Gladwin Friday 12 Noon. Friends may visit Lynch &
Sons Funeral Home, 340 Pontiac Trail Walled Lake (3 Blks. S. of Maple Rd.) Wednesday
3-9 p.m. (Rosary 7 p.m.).

Memorials to Sacred Heart School in Gladwin appreciated. Condolences at
www.LynchFuneralDirectors.com

title: Joseph A Blanger Death
ocr_text:
Joseph A. Belanger, 58, of Ypsilanti, passed away Wednesday, June 15, 2005 at the VA
Medical Center in Ann Arbor. He was born in Ann Arbor on Feb. 9, 1947 to Stanley and
Margaret (Barkume) Belanger. He was a proud Marine who served his country during
the Vietnam conflict. He was a highly educated individual with a constant thirst for
knowledge.

He is survived by two daughters, Anna Belanger of Florida and Daphne Belanger of
Amsterdam; his parents, Deacon Stanley and Margaret Belanger of Walled Lake; four
brothers, Bernard (Linda) Belanger of Westland, John Belanger of Canton, Bob (Diane)
Belanger of Farmington, and James (Brenda) Belanger of Ypsilanti; five sisters, Helen
(Jim) McGuire of Northville, Frances Mandaville of Westland, Bernadette Belanger of
Northville, Annette Belanger and Rene (Jim) Bosman, both of Lansing; and several
nieces and nephews.

Funeral liturgy will be celebrated at 1 p.m. on Friday, June 24 at Sacred Heart Catholic
Church with the Rev. Fr. Patrick Jankowiak presiding. Burial will be at Sacred Heart
Catholic Cemetery. Belanger will lie in state at the church on Friday from 11 a.m. until
the time of service. Memorials may be made out to "wishes of the family." The Sisson
Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements. Gladwin County Record dated 6-22-
2005.

title: Stanley A Belanger Death
ocr_text:
Belanger Stanley Anthony Deacon

Age: 88

Gladwin County Record, Jul 24, 2007

Belanger Stanley Anthony Deacon, Oct. 2, 1919 to July 21, 2007 ordained Aug. 13, 1972.
Loving husband of 67 years to Margaret Mary (Barkume).

Greatly loved and admired father of 13 children, 30 grandchildren and 31 great-
grandchildren. Baby brother to three sisters, and proud WWII war hero of the 2nd
Marine Division.

Because of you our roots are strong, and your stories and laughter will live forever.

Funeral mass was held at St. William Catholic Church on Tuesday and interment at
Sacred Heart Cemetery at 11:30 a.m. on Wednesday.

Memorials to Sacred Heart School, 300 N. Silverleaf, Gladwin, MI 48624.

February 23, 1928 - July 3, 2021
Stanley Theodore Brockway passed away July 1,2021. He was 83 years old. Born on
Febuary 23, 1928, he had ale wel lived. He served in WW and the Korean
‘Occupation in the US. Air Force asa crew chief of aP-51. He was proud to work at
Detroit Edison for 37 years, and receiving the lex Dow award in 1957 forsavinga
‘man's ife while on the job. He had long and loving marriages to his fest wife Margaret,
‘and second wife Lena. He will be eemembered for his optimistic outlook, and love for
his family. He enjoyed boating, and was very proud of his family

He is survived by his loving children Bradley (Donna) Brockway, Peggy (Steve) Bracey,
Bruce (etsy) Brockway, Daniel Cadigan, Denise (Paul) Blazek, Diane (Butch) Lack,
numerous adoring grandchildren, great grandchildren, great great grandchildren, and
nigces and nephews. He was predeceased in death by his wives Margaret and Lena,
‘daughter Denise (Bruce) Armstrong, on Patrick Cadigan, sister Lorna Kryk and brother
lena Brockway. Our thanks to his "Sunrise Brighton Gardens Family" for welcoming
him in so warmly and making his ast years fun,

He willbe missed, and our grateful heart wil forever treasure his memory.

Molnar Funeral Home Michigan

title: Photo
ocr_text:
FREEP.COM | SUNDAY, JULY 4, 2021 | 29A |

Stanley Theodore Brockway

Stanley Theodore Brock-
way passed away July 1, 2021.
He was 93 years old. Born on
February 23, 1928, he had a
life well lived. He served in
WWII and the Korean Occu-
pation in the U.S. Air Force as
a crew chief of a P-51. He was
proud to work at Detroit Edi-
son for 37 years, and received
the Alex Dow award in 1957
for saving a man’s life while
on the job. He had long and loving marriages to his first
wife Margaret, and second wife Lena. He will be remem-
bered for his optimistic outlook, and love for his family.
He enjoyed boating, and was very proud of his family.

He is survived by his loving children Bradley (Donna)
Brockway, Peggy (Steve) Bracey, Bruce (Betsy) Brockway,
Daniel Cadigan, Denise (Paul) Blazek, Diane (Butch) Lack,
numerous adoring grandchildren, great grandchildren,
great great grandchildren, and nieces and nephews. He
was predeceased in death by his wives Margaret and Lena,
daughter Denise (Bruce) Armstrong, son Patrick Cadigan,
sister Lorna Kryk and brother Glenn Brockway. Our thanks
to his “Sunrise Brighton Gardens Family” for welcoming
him in so warmly and making his last years fun.

He will be missed, and our grateful hearts will forever
treasure his memory.

In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to dav.org
(Disabled American Vets), and alz.org (Alzheimers As-
sociation).

Instate, Wednesday, July 7, 2021, 11:30 AM until time of
Mass at 12:30 PM, St. Kenneth Church, 14951 N. Haggerty
Rd., Plymouth.

Arrangements by Molnar Funeral Homes - Brownstown
Chapel.www.molnarfuneralhome.com.

title: John and John George Woodling
ocr_text:
SNYDER COUNTY PIONEERS

JOHN WOODLING was born on
January 31, 1776, presumably in
Frederick Township, Montgomery
County, Pa. and seems to have
been a son of John Woodling who
ilved in Philadelphia, later Mont-
gomery County. He died in what is
now Penn Township, Snyder Coun-
ty, and is buried in the cemetery
of the First Lutheran Church m
Selinsgrove, Pa. His tombstone in-
dicates that he died on Septemb-r
19, 1860, but due to the fact that
his will was probated at Lewisburg,
Pa., on March 1, 1853, the date of
“1860” must be incorrect. His wife
was named Susanna
John seems to have come to what
is now Snyder County with his bro-
ther, John George, on cattle buy-
ing trips as early as 1790, and
some time prior to 1800, both bro-
thers settled in the Middle Creck
Valley. John bought and sold vari-
ous tracts of land in what is now
Penn and Washington Townships.

John mentions thiese chil-
dren in his will: Isaac (1809-
1873), John, Elizabeth (Mrs. Sam-
uel Pawling), Catherine (Mrs.

John Wise), Polly Mrs. Peter Bow-
man), Abraham, Lydia (Mrs. Hen-
ry Wittenemeyer), David, and Ja-
cob. wha married Hannah Pawling,
and died before his father. Isaac,
son of John and Susanna Wood-
ling was baptized at the old Zion
Lutheran Church, north of Free-

burg, in 1809.
JOHN GEORGE WOODLING
(also Woodly, Woodley, Watling,

Wodley, Wodly, etc.) was born on
January 16, 1761, probably in what
is today Frederick Township, Mont-
gomery County, Pa. His father
seems to have been John Woodling.
He also had a brother named John.
Hannah Herb (?), wife of John
George Woodling, was born on Oc-
tober 23, 1762, and died near Free-
burg, Snyder County, Pa., on Sev-
tember 18, 1837. He died about the
year 1845, and is supposed to have
been buried at her side in an un-
marked grave in the St. Peter’s
Cemetery in Freeburg. According
to tradition, “George Woodling” as
he was commonly called. first came
into the Susquehanna Valley about

the year 1790 to buy cattle for the
Philadelphia butchers. These he
drove overland via the “Reading
Road.” His younger brother, John,
mentioned above, accompanied aim
on these trips. After a number of
trips to the section, they became
interested in land in what is now
Penn and Washington ‘Townships,
and at one time they owned the
greater part of what is now known
as the “Sand Hill” and the “Flint-
stone Valley.” George bought the
Flintstone tract about. the year
1798. George Woodling, a great
grand son of the pioneer, aged 80
years in 1934, was the owner of
part of the original purchase of
1798, Irwin Steffen is at present
the owner of most of the remaind-
er of the original purchase. Not any
of the “Sand Hill” land is in the
hands of a Woodling descendant at
this date. About 1795, George and
his brother built the stone gristmill,
near Pawling’s Station on the Mid-
dle Creek in Penn Township. This
mill was still standing in 1934, but
was no longer in active use. It has
variously been known as Wood-
ling’s, Kantzs, Pawling’s, Glass’,
Renninger’s and Boyers’ Mill. The
compiler is a great-great-grandson
of this pioneer and has in his pos-
session a sheet of paper on which
George in his own penmanship in
German script, wrote the names of
himself, wife, and children, with
the dates of their births. The writer
also has numerous other papers
which were written or signed by
the pioneer. He also has a German
Bible published in Nuremberg,
Germany, in 1736, on the flyleaf
of which is written the name of
“George Woodling’” and the fact
that he was an officer of the Free-
burg Church. The children of
George and Hannah Woodling
were; George, born March 14, 1785,

Daniel (April 8, 1788), Magdalena,
(Oct. 25, 1790), Henry (Sept. 5,
1793), Jonas Jan. 26, 1795). Joseph

(June 20, 1796), Samuel (Sept. 27,
1797), and William Aug. 20. 1802).
Daniel lived near Millersburg, Pa.,
in May, 1835. Henry was a soldier
in the War of 1812. Joseph moved
to Center County about 1850, and
died near Millheim or Rebersburg.
William lived most of his life in
Washington Township and is buried
at Freeburg. George, born 1785,
had a son named George, who was
paptized at the old Zion Lutheran
Church, north of Freeburg, in 1808.
His wife was named Elizabeth. ac-
cording to the baptismal records.
George “Wodly” 4of Frederick
Township.. served as a private in
Captain Michael Gaugler’s Com-

101

pany of the Philadelphia County
Militia. Frederick Township at that
time was part of Philadelohia
County, later it belonged to North-
ampton County, and now to Mont-
gomery County. It seems that in
1845, George was living with his
nephew, Jacob Woodling, in Selins-
grove. In that year, Jacob wrota to
Colonel Henry C. Eyer, State Sen-
ator, at Harrisburg, asking if he
could not secure a pension for the
“old man,” and on January 15,
1845, Senator Eyer replied that at
the time he was unable to locate
the service record, but that he
would do what he could. Since no-
thing more came of this, it is pre-
sumed that George died soon after.
Jacob ran a tavern on the Isle o

OLD. SETTLER DIES

Patrick Cadigan,Pioneer of Casco,
Passed Away at Green Bay
Hospital Monday.

‘Patrick Oadigan, Sr. one of the old

settlers of the county, died at St. Vin-
cent’s Hospital at Green Bay last Mon-
day morning after a short illness.

Mr. Cadigan was a native of Canada

‘|having been born at Peterborough in

tbat country seventy-eight years ago.

[In 1877 he came to this coanty and

settled on a farm in the town of Casco
where he hed made bis home since. [He
was'an industrious man and was liked
by all who knew him.

le leaves to mourn his loss one son,
P. F. Cadigan of Casco, one daughter,
Mrs, George Taylor of Toronto, Canada
and seven grand-children, namely, Jer-
emiab, Hannah, Margaret, Anna and
Cecelia Cadigan and Grace and Stanley
Taylor.

The funeral services were held at the
Holy Trinity oburch at Casco on Wed-
nesday morning at ten o'clock, Rev.
Kubale of Kewaunee officiating, and
were very largely attended. The pall
bearers were Thomas Burke, James
Mack, Charies McOalvy, William Dros
sart, Dennis Sullivan and Nicklas|
Murphy.

The Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

gifts to neighborhood kids

OBITUARY

hair.

Mrs. Krampy cherished her fami-
ly and was an excellent mother and
wife, her daughter said in a tele-
phone interview from the family
home.

“She was a good mom,” she said.
She said her mother always told
her, her sister and brother that the
three of them taught her how to
love.

“She taught us right from wrong
and was always there for us,” Mrs.
Locher said.

Mrs. Locher also said her mother
had a good sense of humor and
always made them smile.

She said her mother always
fussed over her grandchildren and
great-grandchildren and never
missed their birthdays. Her mother
looked forward to everyone coming
to her home for holiday dinners,
Mrs. Locher added.

“She is the best person that I have
ever known,” Mrs. Locher said.

Mrs. Locher said she never heard
her mother say anything mean
about anyone else.

Her mother was fond of children
and at Christmastime presented
gifts to neighborhood children,
Mrs. Locher said.

Mrs. Krampy spent 15 years in
the garment industry and retired
in 1980 from Bestform Inc., where
she was a clothing inspector.

Page B7

Mrs. Krampy’s first husband,
Irvin Gossard, died in 1970. She
married Peter Krampy in 1980.

In addition to her daughter, Mrs.
Krampy is survived by her hus
band; two sons, Ronald, Johns-
town, and Larry, East Conemaugh;
six grandchildren; and 12 great-
grandchildren.

The Henderson-Makuchan-Ket-
terer Funeral Home, 434 First St.,
Conemaugh, is in charge of
arrangements.

| in the Pine Grove cemetery on Monday,

For the Warcuman.
Death of Mr. David Krebs, Sr,

It is our sad duty to chronicle the death of
our highly esteemed friend and former
neighbor, which occurred at Spruce Creek,

'Y, on Saturday evening
about 100’clock, of paralysis, at the Breat age
of almost four score years,

The old gentleman had wasted away to a
mere skeleton, and death was a relief to him,
as his mind had become very much impaired
withia the last two years, But a few days
Previous to his death it was thought that he
was improving, being able to walk about and
cheerful. But the fond anticipations of hig
fainuly and friends were blighted when he re.
ceived tae final stroke which calied his spirit
home to Him who gavo it. In his demise
the wife has lost a true and devoted hus-
band, the children and grandchildren a loy-
ing and indulgent father and grandfather.

The deceased was born in Northomberland
e. being in his seyen-
ty-ninth year st the time of his death, He
Was of German descent. About the year

ith hi: ir wid-
migrated to this county,

and together they purchased the farm now
Known as the old Henry Krebs farm. ‘They
Were successful farmers, aud by theit energy
and industry ina few years purchased 300
acres adjoining (raw, barren lands) on which
elegant farm buildings were erected, now
known as the old David Krebs farm, and now
owned by Dr. Hale. Oa this farm Mr. Krebs

i taised large and abundant crops and the

best stock. It was formerly a royal place to
80, Aresort of everybody who wished to be
Kindly entertained and enjoy a good, deli.
cious meal.

Mr. Krebs was possessed with ‘A generous
spirit. Noone ever went to him in wantor
distress and were turned away empty-handed.
He was one of the most hospitable, clever and
genial of mea, He was cheerful, and even
under adverse circumstances managed to see
the brightest side,

In his early life he connected himself with
the Lutheran Chureh, and was one of the

' founders of that Congregation at Pine Grove

Mills, this county, of which he was @ ruling
elder, He was a cheerful giver, and a strong
Pillar in that church. He was also one of
the building committee in the erection of the

!new brick church at that place. His son

was the first person buried in the Pine
Grove cemetery, over half a centary ago.

He was twice married, his first wife having
died over filty years ago, by whom he hai
two sens. One died quite small, the other

i living son, Henry, resides in Pine Grove. Af

ter remaining a widower some eight yea
he married » daughter of John
Kogen, near Pine Grove. The result of this
usion was eleven children, three having
died whilst quite small. Four sons and four
daughters and wife survive his loss.

The deceased w:

The remains of the deceased were interred

Sth inst, at 10 o'clock a. m., amid a circ!

‘tes, |
om -
uly
Tat |
-2/

friends and relatives. Services were held in
the Lutheran Chareh, conducted by Rer.J.
A. Kosen, assisted by Rev. W. C. Kuhns, in
Paying the last tribute to the departed.
Peace to his remains, ste

title: Zimmerman, James M Obituary
ocr_text:
Deati or Jaues M. Zntwenvay.
James M. Zimmerman died at his home
on Lamb street, this place, on Sunday
afternoon about four o'clock after two
days suffering with parslysis. Deceased
‘was 83 years old and had been stricken
with paralysis on the Friday evening
iprevious. He was born in Union coun-
ty, where he resided until thirty yoars
‘ago, when he came’ to this county and
began farming in Boggs township. is
health having failed a few years ago he
sold bis property and moved to this
place where he has lived a retired life
ever since,

‘Ho is aurvived ty # widow with eight
children, among them being’ Calvin,
‘Zimmerman, of Milesburg; Mrs, A.M.
Butler, of Howard, and Misses Mary,
Jeanie and Edith at home.

title: News article about her pg1
ocr_text:
Monday, May 17, 1999

By FRANK SOJAK
THE TRIBUNE-DEMOCRAT

Betty L. Gossard-Krampy of East
Conemaugh, who taught Vacation
Bible School at her church, the
Conemaugh Church of _ the
Brethren, died Saturday at her res-
idence. She was 78.

Mrs. Krampy liked people, espe-
cially children, and that’s why
she enjoyed teaching the Bible
school for children, said her daugh-
ter, Linda Locher of Fairport Har-

bor, Ohio.

She said her mother taught Bible
school during the 1950s and 1960s
when the church was located on
Second Street in East Conemaugh.
The church now is located at 1256
William Penn Ave. in East Taylor
Township.

Mrs. Locher said her mother also
enjoyed going with her Sunday
School class to the Church of the
Brethren Home to visit people and
do tasks such as shampooing their

The Tribune-Democrat, Johnstown, Pa.

Woman gave gifts to neigh

OBITUARY

hair.

Mrs. Krampy cherished her fami-
ly and was an excellent mother and
wife, her daughter said in a tele-
phone interview from the family
home.

“She was a good mom,” she said.
She said her mother always told
her, her sister and brother that the
three of them taught her how to
love.

“She taught us right from wrong
and was always there for us,” Mrs.
Locher said.

Mrs. Locher also said her mother
had a good sense of humor and
always made them smile.

She said her mother always
fussed over her grandchildren and
great-grandchildren and never
missed their birthdays. Her mother
looked forward to everyone coming
to her home for holiday dinners,
Mrs. Locher added.

title: Obituary Tribune-Democrat Johnstown, Pa
ocr_text:
KRAMPY-GOSSARD - Betty L., 78,
East Conemaugh, died May 15, 1999,
at her residence. Born Dec. 23, 1920,
in Johnstown, daughter of late Jeff
and Della (Bennett) Yingling. Pre-
ceded in death by first husband, Ir-
vin Gossard; brothers, James and
John; and grandson, Irvin II. Sur-
vived by husband, Peter, and these
children: Ronald, married to former
Shirley Ofsanko, Johnstown; Larry,
married to former Jo Ann Rosella,
Conemaugh; and Linda, wife of
James Locher, Fairport Harbor,
Ohio; also six grandchildren and 12
great-grandchildren; and stepsister,
Pearl Yingling. Betty was member
of Conemaugh Church of the Breth-
ren, where she taught Bible school.
Retired employee of Bestform Inc.
Friends received from 2 to 4 and 7 to
9 p.m. Monday at Henderson-Maku-
chan-Ketterer Funeral Home, Cone-
maugh, and from 10 until time of
service at 11 a.m. Tuesday at Cone-
maugh Church of the Brethren, the
Rev. Guy L. Myers. Interment, For-
est Lawn Cemetery. Those who
wish may make memorial contribu-
tions to Conemaugh Church of the
Brethren.

title: Obituary
ocr_text:
MICHAEL KOSCHO, 63,
DIES AT NANTY GLO

AFTER LONG ILLNESS |.

NANTY GLO—Michael Koscho,
63, died at 10:30 o'clock last night
at his home on Heisley Avenue
after an illness of a year. He was
born in Europe, but had been a
resident of this section for 37
years, Prior to hia illness he was
employed in the Lincoln Coal Com-
pany mine here.

Surviving are his widow, Mrs.
Anna (Kamorsky) Koscho, and
these children: Anne. wife of Fran-
cis Whinney, Moorefield, W. Va.;
Margaret, wife of Joseph Nagg,
Conemaugh R. D. 1: John and
George Koscho, both of Nanty
Glo; Michael Jr. Helen, Elizabeth
and Agnes, all at home. Seven
grandchildren aand a _ brother,
George Koscho of Universal, Pa.,
also survive.

Funeral services will be con-
ducted at 8 o'clock Tuesday morn-
ing in St. Nicholas Greek Cath-
olic Church by Rev. John Kolecun
of Conemaugh. Interment will be
in the chureh cemetery under the
direction of George Ondriezek, io-
cal mortician.

title: George Koscho Obit
ocr_text:
i catia Ave Fatal p.
To George Koscho:.

i
¥
{

‘A distressing accident occurred in)
the Heisley mine last Wednesday
night, in which George Koscho, aged
36, was so seriously purned that he
died shortly after noon the next day
in Memorial Hospital. |
When a cut)
ting machine,
near which the,
accident victim
was working was)
being moved, it
seems an elec-|
tric spark caused
the explosion of
a pocket of gas.)
Koscho’s cloth-
ing was burned |
from his body)
and he was hor-;
ribly burned

George Koscho about the head,

arms and upper;
part of the body. Samuel Nicol Sr.,|
his, father-in-law, who was working |
a short distance away, was thrown)
down—by_ihe explosion bub was not
badly hurt. Others working nearby |
escaped injury. It was not deter-|
mined immediately whether the ex-|
plosion resulted from an accumula- |
tion of gas, coal dust, or some other |
cause. State mine inspectors have)
since visited the scene of the acci-|
dent but have not announced their
findings. |

The- deceased was a son of the
late Michael Koscho, who passed
away in January, 1940, and Mrs.|
Anna (Kamrosky) Koscho, and was
born here on February 2, 1906. He,
is survived by his mother, his wife,!
Mrs. Margaret (Nicol) Koscho, and
two children, George Jr. and Anna.)
He also leaves the following broth-|
ers and sisters: Mrs. Joseph Nagg,!
Conemaugh R. D. 1; John Koscho|
and Mrs, Chester Adams, Nanty-/
Glo; Mrs, Francis Whinnie, Moore-|
field, W. Va., and Michael, Elizabeth|
jand Helen Koscho at home. |

He was a member of Nanty-Glo|
Local No. 1386, U. M. W. of A. and,
of the Loyal Order of Moose. Fu-/
neral services were held in ‘St.|
Nicholas Greek Catholic Chureh,|
Saturday afternoon, Rev. John Kol-|

cum officiating. ;

title: Christening record for Maria Esther Imler
ocr_text:
gender: Male
Daughter: Maria Esther Imler

https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:V2VK-WZ5

https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:V2VK-WZP

Maria Esther Imler

Pennsylvania, Births and Christenings

Name: Maria Esther Imler

Gender: Female

Event Type: Christening

Event Date: 12 Oct 1735

Event Place: TRINITY EVANGELICAL LUTHERAN CHURCH, NEW HOLLAND, LANCASTER, PENNSYLVANIA
Indexing Project (Batch) Number: C53651-1 , System Origin: Pennsylvania-ODM , GS Film number:
1305845

NOTE: This is not a BIRTH ENTRY, and it takes place almost a month following the D.0.B. listed by
Thomas C. Imler's book, "They Planted A Tree...." and although the location is different from the
location of Birth listed by Thomas Imler the time difference must be considered between Birth &
Christening and the distance of travel is not beyond reasonable efforts. But--BUT, Maria was the second
child of this family, and her older brother Andreas Krafft Imler was born in New Holland and abt. Four
years later Geo. Michael Immler ~ Imler was born in Bedford Co., So~~~New Holland is a strong
probability and will be listed as so.

Maria's Esther Imler's marriage to Johannas Reighard is only found in Thomas C. Imler's book, "They
Planted A Tree In The Wilderness" and can not be found in other files.

According to Thomas's book she and Johannas are buried in the same cemetery, once called
Holderbaum Farm Cemetery but now called Mattas Farm Cemetery, Bedford, Bedford Co., Pa.

DANIEL F, FUNK

| Daniel F. Funk, a former resi-
dént of Tyrone and for the past
ten years g resident of Port Ma-
tilda, died suddenly at his home
at Port Matilda Sunday.

Mr, Funk, who was 56 years old,
was born at Port Matilda.
| On May 20, 1913 he was united |
a marriage with Ethel Crain.
i]

Surviving are his wife and two
daughters: Mrs. Robert Fry and
Miss Dorothy Funk, at home. He

| and sisters: John T, Funk, G.
| Zeek Funk, Mrs. Lioyd Miller and

Mrs, Merrill Williams, all of Ty-|

rone,

He was a member of the Port
Matilda Methodist Episcopal
church,

also survived by these brothers |

title: John M Weakland obit 1903
ocr_text:
Morning Tribune.

‘ Gditorial Department,

=

ALTOONA, OCTOBER 3, 1903.

Prosperous Cambrian Dead.

John M, Weakland, one of the, oldest
residents in Susquehanna township, died
Thursday, September 24, on the same
farm that he lived on nearly all his life.
At his death he owned some ‘of the most
valuable coal land in that section. Mr.
Weakland’s estate is estimated to be no
less than $100,000. Mrs, Weakland, his
aged wife, died December 4, 1902, being
77 years old. The funeral took place at
Carrolltown Saturday.
