title: Adams, George [1856-1925] Death Notice
ocr_text:
GEORGE ADAMS
George Adams a well known resi-
dent of Cresson, died at noon on Mon-
day of heart trouble, having been a
sufferer for a long time. He was born
at Carrolltown, 69 years ago and was
the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas
Adams both deceased. He was mar-
vied at Loretto, in May 1896 to Miss
Catherine O*Neill, who survives with
these sisters: Mrs. Mary McCulty, of
South Fork; Alice Adams, of Altoona,
and Mrs. John MecCulty of Carroll-
town. The deceased had been for a
number of years janitor of the Cres-
son public schools until compelled to

retire by reason of ill health.

title: Catherine O'Neill obituary
ocr_text:
MRS. CATHERINE ADAMS

CRESSON—Funeral service fo
Mrs, Catherine (O'Neill) Adam:
aged 78, whose death occurre
early Saturday morning, will bj
conducted at 9 o'clock this mot
ing in the St. Francis Xavier’
Catholic church. Interment wi
be in the St, Michael's Catholi
church cemetery at Loretto.

She was a life long Cambria:
and was born in Wilmore, a daug}
ter of Felix and Rosalia (McHugh|
O'Neill, one of the eight childr

this union. Her husban
George Adams, preceded her to th
grave many years ago. Survivin
are two sisters and two brother:
Sister M. Theresa, of the Sister]
of Mercy, and Mrs. Elizabeth Wal
ters, both of Cresson, Henry 0}
Neill of Pittsburg and Francis 0}
Neill of South Fork.

title: History of Western Maryland Vol II - John (Johannes) Chrysostum Eckenrode Jr
ocr_text:
850

HISTORY OF WESTERN MARYLAND.

The American Sentinel, published in Westminster, is
a combination of The Regulator. The paper was
bought from Mr. Davidson by Col. John K. Longwell,
who moved the office to Westminster in May, 1833,
and changed its name to The Carrolltonian. The
paper was moved there solely to advocate the forma-
tion of Carroll County. In 1838 a Democratic jour-
nal called The Democrat was established here by Wm.
Shipley, Jr., when The Carrolltonian was announced
as a Whig journal. Col. Longwell continued the
publication of the paper until 1844, when Francis T.
Kerr, a brother-in-law to the late John J. Baumgart-
ner, Esq., succeeded to its proprietorship. Upon the
death of Mr. Kerr in 1846 or 1847, George D. Mil-
ler, of Frederick, took charge of the paper, and was
shortly after succeeded by W. H. Grammer, in 1850.
In 1854, upon the rise of Know-Nothingism, the name
of the paper was changed to the American Sentinel,
its present title.

Among the early physicians were Dr. Joseph Sim
Smith, a patriot in the Revolution and a brave sol-
dier. He died Sept. 6, 1822. William Hubbert
and Dr. Boyle were also among the first physicians in
Taneytown. The latter and Henry Swope were
among the earliest merchants. John White and Jo-
seph Lanubert were the blacksmiths of the village in
the olden time. A tavern was kept by Mary Crouse
in the house now occupied by Mr. Stonesifer as a
hotel, and the Crabsters kept the inn just opposite
and across the street. The following advertisement
appeared in a newspaper of Dec. 16, 1801:

“For sale, the tavern ‘ American Coat of Arms,’ in Taney-
town. Apply to James McSherry, Littlestown, Pennsylvania,
or Richard Coale, Libertytown, Maryland.”

Harney is a small hamlet about four and a half
miles from ‘Taneytown and near the Monocacy River,
which is at this point a small stream. It was named
in honor of the late Gen. Harney, of the United
States army. The United Brethren, a religious de-
nomination, have built a church in the village re-

cently, of which Rev. J. Whitlock is pastor. D. L.
Shoemaker is the village postmaster. A number of

milla are located here, under the charge of William
Starner, John Unger, and Peter Selt. There is a
hotel in the village, kept by W. F. Eckenrode, and
John Eckenrode keeps an assortment of general mer-
chandise. There are also two excellent physicians,
John C. Bush and E. B. Simpson. The population
of the Taneytown District, according to the census of
1880, is 2596.

For many years the old free-school system, which
obtained so extensively in the rural districts of Mary-
land, was in vogue in Carroll County. At the public

schools the children were taught the three R’s,—
“reading, ‘riting, and ’rithmetic,”—and if they de-
sired further education, they either had to teach
themselves or attend one of the many excellent pri-
vate schools within reach. During the civil war
there was an awakening of the public mind to the
advantages of general education, and a cumbersome
system, expensive in character, resulted from inex-
perienced legislation. This was superseded by the
present system, now general throughout all the coun-
ties of the State, which gives all necessary advantages,
and has the additional recommendation of simplicity.
The following is a list of public school trustees for
1881 and 1882 in the Taneytown District :

1. Pine Hill.—William Clutz, Michael Humbert, Charles M.
Hess.

2. Piney Creek.—Franklin Keppert, Daniel Hesson, Richard
Hill.

8. Walnut Grove.—Samuel Brown, Upton Harney, David W-
Bowers.

4, Washington.—No appointments.

5. Oak Grove,—Samuel P. Baumgartner, Henry Eck, Hezekiah
Hahn.

6, 7, and 8. Taneytown, Nos. 1, 2, and 3.—William 8. Rudisell,
Jesse Haugh, Ezra K. Reaver.

9. Oregon.—Gabriel Stover, William W. Koontz, Ezra Stuller.

10. Martin’s.—Valentine Harman, Jacob Shriner, Martin L.
Buffington.

11, Shaw’s.—Daniel Harman, Edward Shorb, William Smith.

The teachers for the term ending April 15, 1881,
were:
1, H. C. Wilt, 53 pupils; 2, 8. F. Hess, 48 pupils; 3, J. H.
Lambert, 51 pupils; 4, J. Ross Galt, 44 pupils; 5, Calvin
T. Fringer, 51 pupils; 6, Levi D. Reid, 55 pupils; 7, Mrs.
Emma L. Forrest, 54 pupils; 8, James F. Fringer, 47 pu-
pils; 9, John T. Reck, 68 pupils; 10, George W. Hess, 51
pupile; 11, C. A. Waesche, 29 pupils; 1 (colored school),
C. H. Stuller, 20 pupils.

The following is the vote for local officers from
1851 to 1861, inclusive:

1851.—Vote for Primary School Commissioners : Israel Hiteshue
190, Benjamin Shunk 155, Iarael Hiteshue 159, John H.
Clabaugh 85, Benjamin Zumbrum 41.

1853.—For Justices: William Haugh 227, George Miller 172,
Benjamin Shank 246, James McKellip 232; Constables:
Thomas Jones, Jy., 250, James Burke 64, John Reindollar
238, David Kephart 87; Road Supervisor: Patrick Burke
108, James Thompson 243.

1855.—For Justices: George Miller 246, William Haugh 248,
Jacob Shriner 249, George Crabbs 132, James Crouse 132,
L. Buffington 137; Constables: Thomas Jones, Jr., 256,

title: Obit of one Michael Weakland
ocr_text:
Deaths in Johnstown.

Thomas Wierman Fulton, son of Mr. John
Fulton, Chief Mining Engineer of the Cam-
bria Iron Company, died at the home of his
parents in Johnstown yesterday. He con-
tracted a cold while attending the School of

Mines, Columbia College, New York, last win-
ter, and had been in delicate health ever
since. He was a bright and promising young
gentleman.

Michael Weakland, a prominent citizen of
Johnstown, died in that place on Sunday.

title: John Weakland obit 1903
ocr_text:
JOHN M. WEAKLAND. :
John M. Weakland, of Susquehanna f
township, Cambria. county, died on
Thursday morning. The deceased was!
born in Indiana county in 1814, but lo-
cated on the farm where he died early
in life. The deceased had been an in-
dustrious man all his life and leaves: a ,
valaable estate. His wife died less than
a yearago but the following children:
survive the parents: Miss Agnes Weak-*
land, at home; Mrs. John Bitters and M.
C. Weakland, of Barnesboro; Mrs. Anson :
Eckenrode and Valentine Weakland, of
Susquehanna township; M. J. Weakland, I
of Chest Springs. Interment was made:

at Carroltown on Saturday.

title: OBIT-Eckenrode Grace McNulty 1998
ocr_text:
ECKENRODE - Grace M. (McNul-
ty), 79, Clay Center, Kan., formerly
of Ebensburg, died Aug. 28, 1998, at
Clay County Medical Center, Kan-
sas. Born March 3, 1919, in Carroll-
town, daughter of late John and An-
na (Adams) MeNulty. Preceded in
death by husband, Isadore; son,
Francis; four brothers; three sisters;
one grandson; one great-grand-
daughter; and two stepsons. Sur-
vived by children, Clinton, and
wife, Joyce, Fort Walton Beach,
Fla; Eugene, Bemidji, Minn.; Pat-
rick, and friend, Pat Bier, Mineral
Point; Mary Grace, wife of William
Bolette, Spangler; Lucy, wife of Jef-
frey Brooks, Naperville, Ill.; Janet,
wife of Rick Hahn, Wakefield, Kan.;
and Theresa, wife of Jerry Albers,
Carbondale, Colo.; stepson, How:
and wife, Bea, Patton; 13 grandchil-
dren; and 15 great-grandchildren.
Sister of Helen Martin, Rockland,
Mass., and Edna Kontorchik, Car-
rolltown. Member of Holy Name
Catholic Church, —_ Ebensburg.
Friends will be received from 7 to 9
p.m. Tuesday at Askew-Houser Fu-
neral Homes Inc., Ebensburg, where
wake service will be held that eve-
ning. Mass of Christian Burial will
be celebrated at 10 a.m, Wednesday
at Holy Name Church, the Rev.
Monsignor Arnold L. Gaus, cele-
brant. Interment, church cemetery.
In lieu of flowers, contributions
may be made to Holy Name Catholic
Church, 500 N. Julian St., Ebens-
burg, Pa. 15931, in Grace’s memory.

title: Newspapers.com - Tyrone Daily Herald - Thu, Dec 21, 1967
ocr_text:
EBENSBURG — State police
from the Washington barracks
Teported Wednesday they have
questioned a number of persons
in connection with the early Sun-
day morning pistol slaying of
Francis Delano Eckenrode, 27, of
Sparta, Ill,, a former resident
here, who was enroute to visit
his critically il) father, Isadore
Eckenrode, 75, who died a few
hours after his son had been
shot, The victim was killed when
he was shot in the head as he
napped in his auto along Route
70, near Washington, Pa,

to 50 acres of land. John Taney mar Elizabeth. dau of Thos Letch-
worth, Sr., so it is obvious that no social stigma was attached to his
‘apprenticeship. His son, John Taney. Jr.. mar Ann Mackall, widow
of Andrew Taneyhill, John Tanev, Sr. died in 1703,

Michael_Taney was apprenticed to- Thos Leichwarth. St, He

were members of St Barmabas Episcoy urch in Queen Ann Par.
ince is church is one of the oldest in that county anc
was erected in 1704 from St Paul's Church in Calvert Co. St Barnabas

is locat on the Largo Road, then

In the last will of Thos Lucas. Sr. made in Prince George Co. Md,
8 Oct 1724, proved in that county 26 Feb 1722 he leaves “one shilli

each fo the of his first mar out of his natural affection
I do bear for them.” He aman is Bnd wife Dorothy as Exocutris
she to have his dwelling plantation during her lifetime. then by
reversion to his eldest son by his 2nd mar. Joby Lucas. “John to pay

is younger brothers. James and Samuel each 500 pounds of tobacco
this to go towards buying each of them land it being his desire
that all of his sons shall have the benefit of their labor when they
reach the age of 18 years: then when all his debts are paid the
balance to be divided among all of his children of his 2nd mar.” Wit
to his will were Edward and Ninian Willett and James Cross. (See
Thre 1. folio 118 of Orphans Crt. Annapolis also will. libre 1. folio
116 Upper Marlboro. wills Annapolis bk 17. p 147.)

The Willett family is said to have come to Marvland from Little
Saxham. Suffolk. Eng. (See Little Saxham Par Reg p 6.)

Pee irerercrverairs on the tax list in Prince George Co. Md. in

to her grandson. Alexander Lucas. The Tce a SRE do not show whic!

Crawford, merchant of Prince George Co. (See P. G. Co Deed libre
AA, folio 146. Annapolis.)

title: Lucas_Genealogy_Book_P45_Thomas
ocr_text:
Lucas Genealogy
By AnnaBelle Kemp, Hollywood, Calif, 1964
http://interactive.ancestry.com/19828/dvm_GenMono004633-00022-1

CHAPTER 5

THOMAS LUCAS OF
PRINCE GEORGE COUNTY, MARYLAND
AND DESCENDANTS

Thomas Lucas, planter, of Prince George Co, Md, is said to have
been born in Eng about 1650; family tradition is that he came directly
to Md from Little am, Suffolk, Eng, arriving on the ship “‘Provi-

arn
dence of Falmouth” in the year 1668; Wil am Prescott, Master of
that ship.

Records of Md show on 16 Feb 1671, Thomas Notley, merchant
of St Mary’s Co, appeared in the courts of Md, with proof of the
right to claim 5650 acres of land in that State (it being due him
for having transported 24 persons to the Providence to inhabit) one
of whom was Thomas Lucas, Sr. (Libre 11 folio 537; also Libre 16,
folio 411, Land Office, Annapolis, Md). This Thomas Notley came
to Md from Dorset, Eng.

Thomas Lucas settled on_250 acres of land in Prince George Co,
which land was a portion of the tract called “Largo” and consisted
originally of 1031 acres and had been granted to Col Minian Beall in
1685. This land was originally in Calvert Co. until Prince e
Co was erected from part of Calvert Co in 1606. Just when Thomas
Lucas acquired this property has not been determined as the old

Calvert Co Court House records were destroyed by fire in 1882.
Beall sold 431 acres of this tract to John Dorlett: 100 acres to Christo-

er Thompson and 250 acres to Daniel Daniellson. the latter one o
ire passengers _on_the “Providence_of Falmouth” in 1668 with
Thomas Lucas. (Rent Rolls libre 4, folio 323.)

i Thompson also took a patent_on a tract of land
called “Whitelaine” on 31 March 1685, which tract was then in
Charles Co, Md later part of Prince George Co, Md.

Thos Lucas also purchased 20 acres of the tract called ‘““Graiden”
on 13 June 1704 from Philip Gittings for the sum of 20 pounds
sterling. including ‘‘all of the houses. buildings. gardens and or-
chards.” This tract of “Graiden” was granted originally to Col
Henry Darnall in 1686. In 1703 Darnall sold it to Philip Gittings
and the tract then consisted of 269 acres. In 1717 Philip Gittings
sold 249 acres to Francis King; the deed states “‘all of this tract except
the 20 acres Gittings had sold to Thomas Lucas. Sr.” The tract of
“Graiden” is located just north of Thomas Lucas’ 250 acres and
adjoins the tract of “Northhampton”™ on the east. which land be-
longed to Thomas Spriggs, Sr. (Libre EC. folio 193. P.G. Co deeds.)
Wit: to the deed of “Graiden” from Gittings to Lucas were John
Jackson and Chas Ridgley. Deed recorded 6 July 1704.

45

title: Lucas_Genealogy_Book_P46
ocr_text:
“Lucas Genealogy”, Page 46;
By AnnaBelle Kemp, The Bookman Press, Los Angeles, Calif, 1964;
https://www.ancestry.com/interactive/19828/dvm_GenMono004633-00023-0

In 1704 Thomas Lucas. Sr, his second wife Dorothy and his
eldest son Thomas Lucas, Jr. were witnesses on the last will of their
near neighbor Thomas Spriggs, Sr.

Thomas Lucas mar twice. There is some question as to the name
of his first wife; in one quarter it is said to have been Dorothy, the
same as that of his second wife, who was Dorothy, dau of Thomas
and Elizabeth Letchworth. (Land Off Rec Acct 5 folio 255 p

apolis. omas Letchworth was a well known Puritan of Calvert
Co, Md and was one of the leading Puritans in that community.

His name is also spelled as Leitchworth. He served in the Lower
House of Md Assembly during the Puritan Regime in 1660; he
also served as Justice of Cavern ob. He acquired de in Calvert Co,
Md, the most important grant being “Letchworth’s Chance” on 22
May 1657 (Libre 2 folio 6). This tract consisted of 1100 acres on the
Upper Cliffs in Calvert Co near Plum Point. This grant be obtained
for having transported eleven persons to Calvert Co, Md “to inhabit.”
This land was located on the Patuxent River south of Governor Josiah
Fendall’s Plantation of “Cool Springs Manor” and just north of the
grant “Mt Pleasant” given to James Berry (or Barry) in 1653.
Letchworth also obtained grants for “Letchworth Hills” and “Letch-
worth’s C s” located in the great swamp at the head of Battle
Creek. etd had two sons. Thos and Joseph; also a dau Ann,
who mar Robert Skinner. (See Hist of Calvert ts by Stein, p 289.)
Thos Letchworth’s wife, Elizabeth was living as late as 1696. In

the last wal of Thos Letchworth. Jr, 30 May 1696, proved 23 Oct
1713, he leaves his entire estate to his son, Thos Letchworth, Jr.
when he reaches the age of 20 yrs; if he does not live. then the
estate to go his mother, Eliza Letchworth. widow of the first Thos
Letchworth; if she is not living. then to his brother-in-law, Robert

Skinner, Testators were Joseph Letchworth” his sister
Letchworth Taney; Thos Earle: Thos Tarvy and A in. Ap-
parently the wife of the Ind Thos Letchworth had died previously.
In the last_will of Robert Skinner 8 Mar 1685, proved 13 Dec
1686 in Calvert Co, Md. he mentions his eldest son. Robert: his dau
Mary Letchworth; his dau Elizabeth, wife of Thos Greenfield, and
s manor sons, Clarke, William and Adderton Skinner. He mentions

his ‘sons-in-law, Jos. Letchworth and’ Thos Greenfield. (See Md Cal
of Wills vol 1, p 102.)

Thos Letchworth. Sr.. had transported two brothers. Michael
and John Taney to the Providence of vid in 1655. John Taney was
apprenticed to Major Thos Truman. Truman took the side of Lord
Baltimore in the War with the Puritans and was captured at the
Battle of the Severn. His possessions were forfeited. including his

rights to the services of John Taney. The records of the Provincial
Courts show that the unexpired term of servitude of John Taney was

purchased by Capt Peter Johnson of Calvert Co, for 5000 pounds of
tobacco. The term of John Taney was completed in 1657 and the
courts ordered Wm. Dorrington, administrator of Peter Johnson’s es-

tate, to furnish John Taney with “three barrels of corn, one waist
coat, one pair of cotton drawers, one pair of shoes, one pair of stock-

46

Research on the Lucas Family Posted: 27 Apr 2000 07:30PM
JL. (View posts)

John M. Lucas Nicholas Lucas, came to Pennsylvania from Maryland, around 1800.
Their father, James Lucas Sr. of Baltimore Md. disinherited them, because they took a
slave with them and ran away to Pa. John settled near Fowler's Saw Mill and was
known as Mountain John. He married Rose Parker, whose father was Amos Packer.
Governor Packer, one time govenor of Pennsylvania was a member of this family.
John And Rose are buried in Lucas Cemetary. Romola, (Curtin Twrp2) Centre Co. Pa
Nicholas and wife Mary, are buried at Sand Hill Cemetary, Centre Co. Pa. (John M.
Lucas Born:12-11-1781 Maryland / Died:1-28-1862(B1yrs.) John's wife (Rose Packer
Lucas Born:10-8-1788 / Died:1-25-1854) Rose's parent's were (Father: Amos Packer /
Mother: Elizabeth Jones ) If anyone can relate to this, contact me. | have MORE!
Thanx J.L.

PHILIPSBURG — Mrs. Amelia’
IF. ry.) 83, a resident of 406 Sixth
St., Philipsburg, died at her home
Tuesday at 4:45 p. m.

Born Sept. 11, 1874, at Julian,
she was a daughter of Wiliam and
‘Mary (Dillon) Lucas, She had made|
¢ home in Philipsburg for the

t GO years.

Surviving are these children: Al-
bert and Wiliam, both at home;
Edward, Mill Hall; Mrs Emma

Mrs. Cora Dixon, and Richard, all

istown; Mrs. Said Tressler, Belle-|
fuate; and George Lucas, Allport.
‘Also surviving are 27 grandchil-

by her husband, Edward S, in
1956.

Funeral Home in Philipsburg with

burg Cemetery.

Harry A. Kreps, 82

SUNBURY — Harry A. Kreps, 82,
of 530 N. Seventh St., formerly of 144
Linden St., died Christmas eve at Sun-
bury Community Hospital where he
was a resident of the nursing care unit
since since November 1987.

Born in Northumberland, June 24,
1906, he was a son of the late Edward
and Mary Frances (Frye) Kreps. His
first wife, the former Beatrice Ray,
died in 1948. His second wife, Anna
Patterson, died in 1974

Mr. Kreps was a conductor for the
Penn Central Railroad Co. and retired
in 1971 with 30 years of service. He
was of the Methodist faith, and was a
member of the Moose and
Sunbury Eagles; Hookies Fire Com-
pany, and No. | Fire Company, both of

iorthumberland; a life member of
the Americus Hose Company and life
member of the Hummels Fire
Company; Point Township Fire Com-
pany; Brotherhood of Rai Train-
men; social member of the Northum-
berland VFW; and a social member of
Ents Gents.

He_is survived by a dat

Mary F. Rine} of Northumber!

two great-grandchil-
dren! and two half brothers, James
Wallace of Northumberland and Rus-
sell Wallace of Pittsburgh.

The funeral will be conducted at 10
a.m. Wednesday in the Zweier Fune-
ral Home, Sunbury, by the Rev. Vi-
tolds Gobins of the United Lutheran
Church, Sunbury RD. Burial will be in
West Side Cemetery, Shamokin Dam.

Visitors may call in the funeral
home from 9 a.m. to the time of the
service Wednesday

Mrs. Lethea E. Fry

DANVILLE — Mrs. Lethea E. Fry, 82,
of 404 E. Market St. died Saturday morn-
ing in the Geisinger Medical Center,
Danville.

Born in Stillwater Jan. 11, 1896, she
was a daughter of the late Harry Viola
Johnson Robbins. She was married to
Aaron Fry, who died in 1926.

Mrs. Fry was a member of Straub's
Lutheran Church, Strawberry Ridge:

Survivors include two sons, Aaron and
Earl William Frv}| both of Danville; a
daughter, Mrs. Maynard Umstead of
Danville; a brother, Earle Robbins of
Croydon; 22 grandchildren and 47 great-
grandchidren.

The funeral will be conducted Tuesday
at 2 p.m. in St. Paul's Straub Lutheran
Church, Strawberry Ridge by the Rev.
Thomas E. Light, pastor of Straub’s
Lutheran Church and the Rev. O. Allen
Lumpkin, chaplain of the Geisinger Me-
dical Center, officiating. Burial will be
in the Odd Fellows Ci . Danville.

Friends may call at the John J. Brady
Funeral Home Monday from 7 to 9 p.m.
and at the church Tuesday from noon
until time of the service.

title: Edna G Hamor b 1883 obit
ocr_text:
The Daily Item (Sunbury, Pennsylvania) . 11 Nov 1948, Thu + Page 10 GP

1 of 5 matches | ¢

Mrs. Edna Fry./64,

Dies In Hospital

Mrs. Edna Hamor Fry, of 260
Queen street, died today at 2:55 a.
m. in Community Hospital after
several weeks of illness. She had
been a patient in the hospital since
Wednesday 4fternoon at about 3
| o'clock when admitted by Ameri-
|cus Ambulance. -Death was due
to a heart condition. She was 64
years of age.

Widow of the late Aaron Fry,
well known farmer in this area
who died 23 years ago, Mrs. Fry
was a daughter of the late Mack
jand Minnie Grady Hamor. She
was born in Northumberland Dec-

ember 18, 1883 and had spent all
her life here.

Survivors include a_ brother,
Walter Hamor, of Honesdale and

a sister, Mrs. James Hoopes, of,

Falson, Pa. Other survivors in-
clude a number of cousins, ne-
phews and nieces in this vicinity.
Funeral services are in charge
of R, L. Davis and Son and will be
announced tomorrow after the ar-
rival of Mrs. Hoopes. Burial will
probably be made in Riverview
cemetery and from the Davis fun-

| eral home.

Methodist Trustees Plan
Property Improvements

Plans for additional work to the
church property were made at a
meeting of the trustees of the Nor-
thumberland . Methodist Church

title: Obituary for ANNIE M. DEAVEN (Aged 97)
ocr_text:
ANNIE M. DEAVEN, 97
North Star Road, North Sta
merly of Pine Grove, Pa., died
Monday in Christiana Hospital.

Mrs. Deaven was a homemaker.
Her husband, Harry B., died in
1964

Survivors: son, Donald of Lan-
denberg, Pa.; daughter, Marie J.
Neal, with whom she lived; seven
grandchildren; 12 great-grandchil-
dren.

Services: 11 a.m. Thursday, Do-
herty Funeral Home, 3200 Lime-
stone Road, Pike Creek. Visitation:
10 a.m, Burial: 2:30 p.m. Thursday,
St. John’s Lutheran Cemetery,
Pine Grove.

Contributions: Newark Congre-
gation of Jehovah's Witnesses,
Newark.

Johann George and Eve (Bross) Stormer

The parents of Johann Adam Stormer
(1793-1868) "the canal Lock keeper"

Johann George Stormer, known by George and
his wife Eva Stormer, lived in Shrewsbury Twp. in
York Co.Pennsylvania, They were farmers, and
they owned a 260 acre farm, and raised their
seven children here, they had a young son Jacob
whom died in childhood,

Johannes Geroge Stormer Eva (Bross) Stormer
(1757 - 1810) "George" (1768 - 12/9/1839)

Their Children:

John Stormer (9/12/1785 -
‘J. George Stormer Jr. (2/5/1789 -

Eve Stormer, Mrs. Andrew Sweitzer (1789 2)
Johannes "Adam" Stormer (1/8/1793 - 1868) *
Christina Stormer, Mrs. Michael Seitz

Peter Stormer

Catherine Stormer (9/30/1796 - sl. in 1840)

Johan George Stormer , known by George, was
bom in Pennsyivania, in 1757, he was the son of
Johann George H. Stormer ( 1706 - 1777) (also
spelt Sturmer or Stuerman ). His father, George
H. was from Germany, and came to America, in
1749. George's wife, mother of George (Jr),
was Anna Rosina (Mueller) (10/24/1715 -
7/3/1785),, she was also from one of the German
kingdoms. Anna was the daughter of a Melchoir
Mueller. George and Anna were married in
Pennsyivania, in York Co., on 2/10/1754. They
resided here all of their ives, had a family, and
were farmers.

Johannes "John" and Eva Seitz
Parents of Mary Eliza (Seitz) Stormer - (1803-1885)
Johannes "John" Seitz was born in Lancaster Co., Pennsylvania , on
7/13/1763, the son of Johannes Joseph and Anna Seitz. John grew,
up in Shrewsbury Twp, in York Co. John married Miss Eva Elizabeth
Klinefelter, in 1786. Eva was born on 11/21/1766, also in Shrewsb
Twp. Eva was the daughter of Michael Klinefelter, and his first wife,
Apollonia (Gerberich) Klinefelter, who died when Eva was only 14
years old. Eva grew up on the family farm, and when Eva was a yo.
irl, her parents had a spinning wheel made for her, for cloth making,
John and Eva had a farm in Shrewsbury Twp, where they had their children.
Johannes "John" Seitz and Eva Elizabeth (Klinefelter) Seitz
(7/43/1763 - 1824) (11/21/1766 - 1832)

1. Adam Seitz (3726/1787 - 1870c.) [twins] Their Ten Children

6 Joseph Seitz (11/17/1795 -

10 Barbara Seitz (8/16/1805 - 4/26/1885) (1/1793 - 1868)

Johannes *John’ Seitz, was the son of Johann "Joseph" Seitz (11/4/1729 - 1810).
[Joseph was bom in Meisenheim, Bad Kreuzuach, Rheimland, (Germany) | John’s
mother was, Anna Elizabeth, (1734 - 1810c). Anra was also German, and they
married on 7/13/1763, in PennsyNvania. * Seitz was also spelt as Sides.

Johann Michael Klinefelter and his wife, Apollonia (Gerberich)
(6/10/1736 - 7/17/1807) (1736 - 1780)
Michael was bom in Hessen, a German kingdom, on June 10,1736.
Michael came to America as a young man, and settled in Shrewsbut)
‘Twp. Michael served in Capt. John Miller's company, as a Private, in
the American Revolutionary War. His first wife, Apollonia died at 44,
and he would remarry to a Maria Elizabeth. He would have 17 childre
between his two wives. He and his wives are buried in the Fissel NeW!
Hope Cemetery, in Shrewsbury Twp.. in York Co. Pa. They have th’
ancient grave stones, and a veterans’ flag holder marks his burial si

title: william e stormer
ocr_text:
JEFFERSON COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA

WILLIAM E. STORMER is one of the
progressive and successful business men of the
younger generation in his native county and is
a representative of one of the pioneer families
of this section of the Keystone State. He
owns and conducts a splendidly appointed
grocery establishment in the thriving little
borough of Reynoldsville.

Mr. Stormer was born in Ringgold town-
ship, this county, on the 14th of May, 1888,
and his father, John Stormer, died on the
1st of the following August, at the age of fifty-
eight years, five months, thirteen days. He
was born in Westmoreland county and was

a son of John Stormer, Sr., who was born and
reared in Germany and came to the United
States when a young man. John Stormer,
Sr., settled in Westmoreland county, Pa.,
where he cleared and improved a productive
farm, and later in life passed a number of
years in the home of his son Joseph, in Pine-
creek township, Jefferson county, but passed
the closing period of his life in Westmore-
land county, where he died at a venerable age.
In that county also died his eldest son, Noah,
and also the second son, Levi; Joseph became
a successful farmer in Pinecreek township,
where he passed the remainder of his life;
John, Jr., father of William E. Stormer, was
the fourth son; Samuel, who was a veteran
of the Civil war, died in Pinecreek township;
Michael likewise was a valiant soldier in the
same conflict and passed the closing years
of his life in the Pennsylvania Soldiers’ Home
at Erie; and the daughters were Sarah, Susan
and Polly.

John Stormer, Jr., came to Jefferson county
when a young man and became actively con-
cerned in extensive lumbering operations, in
association with a man named Neal. He later
purchased a property in Ringgold township,
known as the “Hogback” farm, and to its man-
agement he continued to give his attention
until his death. He wedded Chesta Bussard,
who now lives at Worthville, this county, and
they became the parents of nine children, John,
Samuel, Charles, Ada, Jessie, William E., V.
CoG. and Elizabeth. Samuel is a merchant
at Worthville; Ada is the wife of Robert
Stewart; Jessie is the wife of Clark Mauk;
V. C. resides at Punxsutawney; I. C. at Rey-
noldsville; and Elizabeth remains with her
venerable mother at Worthville. After the
death of her first husband Mrs. Chesta (Bus-
sard) Stormer became the wife of William
Eisenhart, who was born at Shamokin, North-
umberland county, and came to Jefferson
county when a young man. He was a black-
smith by trade, but became identified with
lumbering operations, besides having con-
ducted a general store at Sprankle Mills. He
died in 1905, at the age of seventy-nine years,
no children having been born of his marriage
to Mrs. Stormer. Samuel Bussard, the father
of Mrs. Stormer-Eisenhart, was born in
Schuylkill county, Pa., and shortly after his
marriage to Catherine Hepler, likewise a
native of Schuylkill county, came to Jefferson
county, and became a pioneer farmer near
Brookville, where they passed the remainder
of their lives. Of their children the eldest
was Samuel; Harriet became the wife of

609

James Kelly; Chesta, mother of William E.
Stormer, was the next in order of birth;
Amanda married William Keihl; John is a
resident of Armstrong county; Elias is de-
ceased.

William E. Stormer went to the public
schools at Sprankle Mills and at the age of
nineteen years established a meat market at
Reynoldsville which he continued with suc-
cess about ten years, and then engaged in the
grocery business, with like results. It is con-
ceded that his establishment is one of the best
appointed and most metropolitan of its kind in
Jefferson county, and his attractive display of
staple and fancy groceries and other lines of
food products is a model of sanitary arrange-
ment and gastronomical attractiveness. His
store building, with a frontage of fifty-eight
feet, occupies the most eligible and valuable
corner in the business district of Reynolds-
ville. The property was purchased by him
in 1914, though he has been here engaged in
the grocery business since July, 1906.

Mr. Stormer is a charter member of the
Reynoldsville Chamber of Commerce and a
stanch supporter of its high civic and business
policies, with a deep interest in all things per-
tinent to the welfare and progress of his
home city and county. He is a member of the
local board of health, is affiliated with the
Knights of Pythias, and is a Republican in
his political adherency.

In 1901 was recorded the marriage of Mr.
Stormer to Mary E. Bussard, who was born
and reared in this county, and they have three
children, Marion, Lena and Delvin.

title: Obituary for Mary Catherine Reytnef (Aged 80)
ocr_text:
MRS. MARY SONES

Mra, Mary Catherine Reymet
Sones, 89, former resident of Port
Matilda RD, died this morning at
the home of her son Roy, of Over-
look Heights, State College.

She was born Oct. 9, 1860 in
Freeburg, the daughter of the jate
Sarah and John Reymer. She was
married to the late George Sones,
who died April 24, 1936. She was @
member of the Free Methodist
Church, Tyrone. She ts survived by
three daughters and a son, Mrs.
Richard Fink, Lewistown; Mrs
James Frye, Port Matilda; Mrs.
Violet Richards, Tyrone, and Roy,
Stale College.

Funeral service will be held |
Tuesday at 2 p.m, at the Bennett
Funeral Home, Port Matilda, in |

charge of the Rev. H. B. Burket
officiating. Burial will be in Bald
Engle Cemetery. Friends will be
received at the funeral home from
7 p.m, Sunday and until time of
service.

cerificate.

Olive Amy FryfHary Geyer bom Feb 72, 1898 marnied Nov. 17, 1973 died March 15 1958 (This is my grandmother}
Nellie Fry bom Nov 21 1905 still alive idid William come back for a visit?)

Cane filed for divorce in 1903, saying William T. Fry abandoned her April 28th 1897. He was fixing in Lebanon Pennsyivania
Feb 13 1903 when he received ihe subpoena for divorce.

Carnie Swisher and her parenis musi have been very bitler as his name was noi mentioned much in the femily His daughters

So Willam nas been a big mystery to us. We do not know if he remaried or when he died. in fact we know more about

title: Life Sketches of Aged People-page 3 of 5
ocr_text:
|
i
|
|
i

can be found today, according to Mrs. Walborn.

At home Mother Ramer made cloth from wool and flax on a
Spinning wheel for clothing for her family while shoes were made by
Jacob Werick, of Liverpool, where they were measured for new foot-
gear.

The children all ran barefoot during the summer and continued to
do so until the late fall, frequently when frost was thick upon the
ground. The children attended church and Sunday school, barefoot,
going to Liverpool to the Lutheran and Reformed Church, there being
no house ef worship in Hunter's Valley at that time. The family
usually walked to Liverpool where their nearest store and post office
were located.

The Ramer home was constructed of logs, the opening between the
logs being plastered with mud, the barn also being of logs. Floors
in the home were without carpets and were kept clean with soap, sand
and water and a hickory broom, made by Father Ramer. Horses were used
on the farm but Elizabeth recalls seeing many oxen working on farms and
drawing wagon loads of produce, as many as six oxen attached to a
wagon.

Each fall the Ramer's boiled many gallons of apple butter, hold-
ing snitzing parties four or five times during the season, Every-
body had a good time at these snitzing parties, which were pract~
ically the only forms of social gathering held in the valley. Much
of the apple butter was used by the family youngsters as they knew
nothing about molasses or other spreads. Some of it was taken to
Harrisburg and sold or exchanged for merchandise.

For many years the closest flour mill was at Dauphin, then
called Greensburg. Hunter's Valley residents drove to Clark's Ferry,
crossed the old wooden bridge and on to Dauphin with their grain.
Some merchandise was brought to Liverpool on rafts and crops shipped
away the same way. Canal boats also furnished @ means of trans-
portation for the Hunter's Valley farmers.

When Elizabeth was a little girl, at home, Liverpool was a
thriving canal boat and raft town larger than Millersburg. Crow's
Ferry was in operation between Millersburg and the East end of
Hunter's Valley, at the same place the Millersburg Ferry, operated
by Hunter and Radle, is now located. The course was practically
the same at that time, but Elizabeth says ferryman, who were fore
fathers of the present generation of the Crows residing in Hunter's
Valley, had no power boats, They had large flat boats which they
Propelled with poles. She says when the river was low, during the
summer months, the ferrymen did not lay up a ferry wall to increase
the depth of water in the channel, as is done now, but when it was
wuite difflicult to pole a flat across the river the farmers drove
from one side to the other. During the winter, when the river was
frozen over solidly, farmers crossed on the ice with loads of grain

147

Friday, October ?, 1932
LIFE SKETCHES OF AGED PEOPLE
of Millersburg and Surrounding Areas
ELIZABETH WALBORN, 89, OF HUNTER'S STATION

Recalls Stories of Indians, Wolves and Wild Cats--Deep Snow
Blocked Roads Frequently Years Ago-Parents Raised Thou-

sands of Bushels of Apples and Peaches-Remembers

Liverpool as Thriving Canal Boat and Raft Town--

Tells of Crow's Ferry in Olden Days

1-2-1-7-5-5- by--F. Park Campbell, Associate Editor
Elizabeth Walborn, widow of Jacob Walborn,

home of her son, George E. Walborn,

R.D.#1,

who resides at the

at Hunters! Station, Trevorton

will be 90 years old if she lives until April and she belives

her long life is due to the fact that she has always lived on a farm

where she worked long hours in the fresh
Mrs. Walborn,

air and sunshine.

is a daughter of the late Joseph and Annie Aucker

Ramer and was born in Hunter's Valley, Perry County, opposite Miller-

sburg April 3, 1843. Her grandfather, John Ramer, was one of the first
settlers in Hunter's Valley,

going there from Lancaster County. He
located on a tract.of land along the south side of the Liverpool

mountain about 12 miles back from the Susquehanna river. At that
time Hunter'

S Valley was practically all timber land and wild animals
and Indians roamed about.

Elizabeth recalls hearing her grandfather and her fath
of the Indians in Hunter!

er tell

s Valley and about wolves and wild cats.
Wild animals were so plentiful and bold that when Grandfather Ramer
and his sons left the home Premises for a day all of their livestock
had to be penned up in a tight enclosure so bears and
not kill and carry away the farm animals

wolves could

John Ramer and his sons cleared their tract of land in due time

and later Joseph, a son, became the owner of more than 100 acres.
Joseph Ramer and his good wife, Annie,

reared a family of ten children
Mrs.

Elizabeth Walborn being the last surviving member. Elizabeth
recalls attending a small school in Hunter's Valley, near the site of
the present Hebel's school and while school was in session only three
months during her young days because of so much work at home. She
never learned to write and has never been able to write her own name
although she could read and continued to do so until within the last
Several years, when her eyesight began failing.

She tells of the deep snows which
go that the school children w
to school. .

blocked the roads frequently
ere compelled to cross fields to get

The Ramers grew thousands of bushels of apples and peaches on

their farm and good crops of wheat and oats with no near market for

the disposal of the fruit and grain. Father Ramer made frequent trips
to Harrisburg with wagon loads of farm produce,
back requiring two days.

title: Life Sketches of Aged People-page 5 of 5
ocr_text:
George Walborn, who after the close of the Civil war, became ill on
his way home. He served in the Union Army, and died before he reached
home. Another brother, Charles Walborn passed away in Williamsport.

Mr. & Mrs. Walborn had seven children, four of whom are living
today. They are Milton Walborn, Portland Oregon; George Walborn,
Hunter's Station and Mrs. Emma Walborn Shaffer, Pillow.

Referring to her young days on. the farm, during a most delightful
interview at the Walborn home, last Sunday morning, this grand old lady
declared that in those early days there were very few insect pests to
contend with and that no one knew anything about spraying fruit and
vegetables. She says she has known about mossquitoes all of her life
but that potato bugs first made their appearance in Pin township
section, 59 years ago, prior to that she had never seen nor heard of
them. These pests appeared in the potato stalks. No one knew what the
pests were that nearly destroyed the potato stalks of a neighbor.

The farmers began trying paris green and other poisons to the bugs.
Since that time nearly every year some new speciman of insect pest or a
new plant disease seems to appear.

Mr. Walborn who was widely known, farmed on a 50-50 basis the
greater part of his life and did not own a farm. Mrs. Walborn told how
her husband frequently caught fish and eels by the bushel, in nets set
in the river. He was a successful hunter and many times the home
larder was replenished with rabbits, squirrels and other small game
bagged by him.

Mr. Walborn passed away 28 years ago and since then the widow has
resided with the family of her son, George Walborn. She has always had
good health, and never had any fever until she became quite aged.

Until she was 70 Mrs. Walborn could work in the fields as well as most
men her age. In 1918 she suffered a fracture of the left leg, above
the knee, in a fall and the fracture never knit properly. Since then,
this fine old lady has been a suffer of rheumatism and for the past
several years cannot walk unaided and remains in her room, in a com-
fortable rocking chair, overlooking the Shamokin highway. At the
present time, with the leaves taking on their autumal colorings, the
mountains and woodland included the view from the bedroom window of
Mrs. Walborn are especially beautiful and she derives quite a bit of
pleasure from just watching the even changing natural scenery.

Mrs. Walborn has never been far away from home and recalls being
in Harrisburg but once in her life, that being when the present capital
building was didicated. She has been to Milton, and one time, 40 years
ago, attended the Gratz Fair. Mrs. Walborn has traveled which included
horse and buggy, canal boat, railroad, trollery car and automible but
she declares she never would get into an airplane.

She has been a member of the Stone Valley church for many years
he oldest members on the church roll.

title: STORY OF THOMAS DENNY'S PARENTS
ocr_text:
Elias own father was killed in the civil war.
Elizabeth Stepp, Elias' mother, was born in
Henderson County, North Carolina. On July 29,
1860, she married Thomas B. Drake. He was
killed fighting in the Civil War in Tennessee.
Elizabeth had a son, Elias B. Drake in 1862,
she married, Columbus Christopher Wright and
he adopted Elias.

Elias Drake Wright's and Serelda Denny's
child's name was Thomas Denny. Thomas was
a very handsome child. He married Martha
Catherine Hurst Denny.

title: _Red Greens_
ocr_text:
Nascent Jacksonian

At the age of seventeen, Green’s great-grandfather, Robert Green,
departed northern Ireland for the American colonies, arriving in Vir-
ginla with his Scots Quaker uncle, Sir William Duff, in 1712. Settling
rst in King George County, Green eventually made his permanent
home near Brandy Station in Orange County, now Culpeper County.
In 1732, Robert, along with his uncle and two other individuals, re-
ceived a patent for 120,000 acres of land, scattered among the counties
of Prince William, Augusta, Orange, Westmoreland, and King George.
Green soon inherited his uncle’s share of the extensive holdings, mak-
ing him one of the largest landowners in colonial Virginia. His owner-
ship of such a vast tract of land enabled him to emerge quickly as one
of Orange County’s leading citizens: captain of the county militia, one
of the first vestrymen of St. Mark’s Parish, and a member of the Vir-
ginia House of Burgesses in 1736. Before his death in 1748, he would
have seven sons, all exceeding six feet in height and sporting red hair
and beards. Known as the “Red Greens,” in order to distinguish them
from other Green families, Robert’s sons would marry into the most
distinguished families in Virginia—Lee, Willis, Barbour, Lewis, Henry,
Price, Bayly, Marshall.”

Duff Green’s grandfather, also named Duff, had married into the
prominent and wealthy Willis family of Virginia, thus adding signifi-
cantly to his own landholdings inherited from his father. Duff had little
time to enjoy his extensive assets. He died in 1766, ten years before the
War of Independence. Duff's brothers, however, would live to serve
with distinction an the Patriot forces during the Amer-
ican Revolution. Dt 5 wid |

James C. Risner, 67,
Pontiac Motors worker

and Mary Margaret (Smith) Risner.

He has been a resident of the Har-
tland-Howell area for the past 29 years.
He was an assembly worker at Pontiac
Motors.

Survivors include: his wife, Nellie
(Denny); eight children: Mrs. Ken

all of Highland, Mrs Dick (Leola)

title: NELLIE AND JAMES
ocr_text:
NELLIE WAS BORN AND RAISED IN CHEROKEE INDIAN TERRITORY
ON THE YELLOW GREEK.

HER MOTHER MARTHA HURST DENNY WAS DEEMED A CHEROKEE
PARENT ON DAWES ROLL CARD 4168 AFTER INTERVIEWS WITH
THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT.

HER DAD, THOMAS DENNY, WAS A CHEROKEE INDIAN RAISED AS
ACHERDKEE AND MARRIED IN A CHEROKEE WEDDING. HIS
SINGLE MOM'S NAME WAS SERELDA DENNY.

THOMAS DENNY WAS DARK AND HANDSOME AND DIED YOUNG.
LIFE WAS DIFFICULT FOR THE DENNY KIDS.

DESPITE HIS FAMILY'S PREJUDICE, JAMES RISNER MARRIED
NELLIE DENNY. AS SHE GAVE BIRTH TO HIS CHILD, AND THEY
MOVED TO HARLAN COUNTY KENTUCKY FOR COAL MINING. THEN,
THEY MOVED TO MICHIGAN SO THEIR CHILDREN COULD BE
EDUCATED, AND JAMES WORKED AT GM.

title: obit. Nicholas M. Altimus Jr.
ocr_text:
ALTIMUS — Nicholas M. Jr., 82, Box
272; Mineral Point R. D. 1, died Sept.
14,-1984, at Memorial Hospital. Born
Féb. 17, 1902, in Jackson Township,
sor of late Nicholas M. Sr. and Pris-
cilla (Dishong) Altimus. Preceded in
death by wife, Jennie May; brothers,
Tieodore and Miles; and _ sisters,
Emma Watson and Nellie Watson.
Survived by these children: Nicholas
V.zSeward R. D. 1, and Glenn L. and
Wayne, both of Erie; also 10 grand-
children and 18 great-grandchildren.
Brother of Nora Holsopple, Oregon,
and Cordilla Watson and Daniel W.,
both of Johnstown R. D. 6. Member of
Christian & Missionary Alliance
Church and Local 1386, UMWA, both
of Nanty Glo. Friends received from
2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday and Mon-
day at Harry R. Ondriezek II Funeral
Home, Nanty Glo. Service at 1 p.m.
Tuesday at Christian & Missionary
Alliance Church, Nanty Glo, the Rev.
Keith. Lindsy. Interment, Forest
Lawn Cemetery.

Peter Hartkopf, Conrad "Im Der Hohe", and Cicilia
Gordts;4 d. 20 Mar. 1685 at age 5 weeks.4
id iv. Wilhelm, bp. 2 Jun. 1686 in Pilghausen; sp.
Clemens Dunckelnberg, Elizabeth Grahe and Ursula
Neeff.4
Wilhelm's second wife, whom he married on 11 October 1695
was Helena Melchiors, daughter of Clemensen Melchiors of Ruden,
Germany. The banns were published on 25 September and the
second and ninth of October 1695./7

Se CLEMENS DUNCKELNBERG ae

Clemens111 Dunckelnberg (8), son of Wilhelm11 (4) and his
first wife,’ Christina (Hartkopf) Dunckelnberg, was baptized 16
September 1682. Witnesses at his baptism were Adolff (1)
Dunckelnberg, Gieles Hartkop and Neisgen Keilier.* On 7 April
1704, Clemens was confirmed and the record stated that he was
residing in Pilghausen at the time. On 5 October 1704 he
married Margaretha Godschalck, daughter of Peter Godschalck and
Anna Kirschner. As can be seen from Solingen baptismal records,
the Godschalcks, Kirschners and Dunckelnbergs were related. A
Peter Godschalck married Anna Kirschner in the Solingen area and
they had a daughter, Maria Margaretta. Also, Martin Kirschner
and Nicolaus Gottschalck came together to America on the Ship
Francis and Elizabeth on 21 September 1742. In 1743 and
subsequently Nicolaus's name appears on the baptismal records of
Moselem Lutheran Church in Richmond Township, Berks County, as
well as on the organizers’ list of that church in 1745. He was
married to Catharina Haas. .

The banns for the marriage of Clemens and Margaretta had
been published from 21 to 28 September 1704.7 They had eleven
children, three of whom were listed on the Mortonhouse (ship)
roster in 1728. There is some evidence to indicate that Clemens
(8) and Margaretha were also on that ship with their younger
children. One bit of evidence to support this theory is that
the confirmation of Hans Peter (15) in the Solingen church
records of April 1727 appears to be the last entry for this
family and Harry I. Dunkleberger has found no record of Clemens'
or Margaretha's death in German church records.8 A second bit
of evidence has already been cited--that of the two Clements
listed on the Mortonhouse's first roster. And the third piece
cf evidence is the fact that Nicolaus Gottschalck and Martin
Kirschner settled in Richmond Township and Nicolaus was one of
the founding members of the Moselem Lutheran Church where
Clemens (12) Dunkelberger attended.

Clemens and Margaretha had eleven children that we know
of.

title: Newspapers.com - Altoona Tribune - 22 Dec 1933 - Page 14
ocr_text:
MRS. SARAH R. BROWN

The funeral of Mrs. Sarah R.
Brown, 87, widow of J. D. Brown,
who died at the home of her daugh-
ter, Mrs. Alex Frantz, 428 Spruce
avenue, yesterday morning, will be
held Saturday morning at-10 o'clock
at the Frantz home and at 2 p. m.
at the Brethren church, Vinco, Pa.
Burial will ;be at Vinco, Mrs.
Brown. leaves the. following chil-
dren: Daniel W. Brown and Mrs.
Aden Grove of Vinco; Mrs, Luther
Wertz of Juniata; Mrs. Alex Frantz
of Altoona, and Mrs. Coy Williams
of Baltimore, Md. Twenty-eight
grandchildren and thirty-one great-
grandchildren also survive.

filename: 1437_1. Indenture of Benjamin Maple of Ipswitch England 8 May 1684__2. Marriage of Elizabeth Lee & Benjam_9fd0967a.jpg
title: 1. Indenture of Benjamin Maple of Ipswitch England 8 May 1684__2. Marriage of Elizabeth Lee & Benjam
ocr_text:
821

CHAPTER 16. EARLY DOCUMENTS

INDENTURE OF BENJAMIN MAPLE OF IPSWICH, ENGLAND

On May 8, 1684, one Benjamin Maple of Ipswich, Suffolk County,
England, age 21, signed an agreement for four years service as a husbandman
in Barbadoes in return for transportation to and keep there. This document,
which has survived the passage of time for 309 years and is now in the keeping
of the Greater London Record Office, is a printed form with spaces for wniting
in particulars. The text is as follows:

THIS INDENTURE: According to the Method made and provided; And by the Order and
Directions of His Sacred Majestie, King CHARLES the Second, of England, etc. And His most
Honourable Privy Council, the Thirteenth day of December Anno 1682. in the Thirty fourth Year
of his said Majesties Reign, (then Printed and Published) Declaring, That wh :Persons at any time,
as are voluntary, free and willing at their own Liberties, to be Retained to srve in any of his
Majesties Foreign Plantations in AMERICA, are to be duely Examined and Bound onely before any
of His Majesties Justics of the Peace, and the same to bear Record in the Court of Sessions, in that
County or City where such Servants shll be so bound. NOW witnesseth, That Benjamin Maple from
Ipswich In the County of Suffolk - - - Aged Twenty One years, doth without any Sinistry means
freely covenant, promise and grant, to and with John Smith of London, Merchant from the day of
the date hereof, until his first and next Arrival in Barbadoes and after, for, and during the Term of
ffour yeares, therein shall as he the said John Smith, his Executors or Assignes shall therein Employ
him accordingly. IN consideration whereof the said John Smith for Himself, his Executors and
Assignes, doth covenant, promise, grant and agree to and with the said Benjamin Maple to pay for
his Passage in the good Ship the Ffriendshipp, Captain Wm. Bodding. Commander, or in any other
Ship thither directly bound, by the Order of the said John Smith, his Executors or Assignes; And to
find and allow him sufficient Meat, Drink, Apparel, Lodging, Washing and other Necessaries, durin
the said term. And in the end thereof such other Allowances, as to others are Given and Granted in
like kind. IN witness whereof the said Parties to these present Indentures have Interchangeably set
their Hands and Seals the cight day of May - - . in the 36th year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lord
the King Anno Dom. 1684.

Sealed & Delivered Benjamin Maple
in the presence of his mark

Examined and bound before me one of his
Majts. Justices of His Court for the County
william goodbourne of Middlesex and before witness - 1

Abra Bayly

MARRIAGE OF ELIZABETH LEE AND BENJAMIN MAPLE

In 1676, West Jersey was purchased by the West Jersey Society, a
group of Quakers. The first settlement of Quakers in America was in 1677 at
Burlington, NJ, founded by 230 Quakers from Londonand Yorkshire. Thomas
Revell was Justice of the Peace and Agent for the West Jersey Society. The
Revell House on E. Pearl St., the oldest house in Burlington, was built in 1685
and is now the New Jersey State Headquarters of the D.A.R.

The handwritten record book of Thomas Revell records the marriage
of Elizabeth Lee and Benjamin Maple on June 4, 1695, as copied from a
photostat of the original supplied by the Office of the Secretary of State for NJ:

ocr_text:
47

veyed his title to Richbell Mott, May 14, 1700, and
Mott sold out his claim November 11, 1708, to John
Cornwall, John Mott, Nathaniel Moore, and Thomas
Read. It is on this section of land that this village of
. Pennington is built, measuring about one mile and three-
eighths from north to south, and from east to west em-
bracing about two square miles. The settlement of the
village probably began near 1708. It was first named
Queenstown, in honor of Queen Anne, the sovereign of
Great Britain. As early as 1747 it began to be called
Pennington, which name it has borne ever since..

The name by which the old congregation was known
in its earliest history was

“THE PEOPLE OF MAIDENHEAD AND HOPEWELL.”

The first authentic evidence that there were Chris-
tian people in this region uniting together for the
maintenance of religious worship, is found in the record
of a deed bearing date 1698-9, March 18th, in which
the Honorable Jeremiah Basse, Esq., Governor of the
Provinces of East and West Jersey, and Thomas Re-
vell, &c., agents of the Honorable the West Jersey
Society in England, convey “for the erecting of a meet-
ing-house, and for burying-ground and school-house,”
one hundred acres of land to “ Ralph Hunt, John Bain-
bridge, Johannes Lawrenson, William Hixon, John
Bryerly, Samuel Hunt, Theophilus Phillips, Jonathan,

filename: 1442_History of Benjamin Maple's (Sr) Indebtudure For Servitude or Slavery_24ddc8c5.jpg
title: History of Benjamin Maple's (Sr) Indebtudure For Servitude or Slavery
ocr_text:
INDENTURE FOR SERVITUDE OR SLAVERY

His descendants were farming BOEING AIRFIELD in 1851

IN 1684, BENJAMIN MAPLE, TWENTY-ONE YEARS OLD, OF IPSWITCH, COUNTY OF SUF-
FOLK, England, scratched his “x" on an indenture, and thus contracted to work as a hus-
bander (field worker) in the Barbadoes for four years, as payment for passage to those
istands. Note that his contract is on a form depressingly parallel to a 1970 welfare applica-
lion. The mass produced form gives one an inkling of the magnitude of King Charles II's
excess labor problem as well as his socially hazardous distribution of wealth. Evan his throne
was precarious. A parvenue Parliament had removed King Charles !'s head for gross dis-
obedience.

An indigents’ life in England was grim. He ran the risk of starvation, a debtors prison, and
criminal laws that held property to be more valuable than life. Picking a pocket in excess of
a shilling was among the 200 crimes punishable by death. An estimated 40.000 debtors were
jailed annuaily. One prison was called “prototype of hell”. Thus to many, an indenture was
luck; an escape from tyranny. Only four years of hard labor for a 4000 mile sail to the Bar-
bados was a bargain. The going rate to the mainland was seven.

lL is interesting to speculate what affect Englands’ merciless laws, which bred this type of
slavery, liad on the ability of the Continental Congress to raise an army to fight the long and
bloody Revolutionary War. Popular history hooks avoid the details of slavery as those facts
are too repugnant for readers. This is unfortunate in a democracy, since those whe do not
iearn the lessons of history are forced to repeai them. No autobiographies have been handed
down through history telling of the plight of the majority of the silent slaves who were poor,
while some very few lucky ones became wealthy and published their own stories. The buyer
had absolute property in them: could sell them. and found they did not have to be as care-
ful with them as with negro slaves since they were not owned for fife. Furthermore, a
“servant” could go into debt during his first servitude which forced him into another term
to pay off his debt, etc.

The sons and grandsons of indentured servants, who had known only abject poverty for
generations, formed a hard core of militants. Willing to do the bleeding for a personal cause,
they helped defeat the Establishment far out of proportion to their numbers. The 100%
volunteer American Army was miserably fed, ill paid, and clothed so badly that some wore
rags for boots in winter snow. There was no promise of fame or fortune for the troops. Their
indomitable will to fight needed more fuel than that provided by a Boston Tea Party or brave
generals. The fuel came from the hearts of angry men in the ranks. What the kinsmen of In-
denatured Servants condemned as cruel, unjust “Slavery”. the King fram his viewpoint righi-
iully named it “Servitude™. Alas, like beauty, Justice is in the eyes of the beholder.

The descendents of Benjamin Maple fought in the American Army. For one and a half cen-
iuries there were Maple frontier farmers with large families who pioneered always westward.
Theirs was a persistant quest for space and freedom; the consiant surge af population drove
ihem deeper into the vanishing wilderness. From about 1720 free Maples lived in New Jersey
{0 push on to Pennsylvania, to Ohio, to lowa. when they leaped half the continent to be
finally stopped by the Pacific Ocean. They participated in the California Gold Rush in 1850:
they consiituted half of the first party that settled King County, Washington. Part of Boeing
Airfield, Seattle, was a Maple Farm.

‘© 1972 ROBERT MAPLE NORMAN

filename: 1445_1. Marriage of Elizabeth Lee & Benjamin Maple 4 Jun 1695 Cont.__2. Maidenhead Deed__3. Maidenhead Su_e3e643d5.jpg
title: 1. Marriage of Elizabeth Lee & Benjamin Maple 4 Jun 1695 Cont.__2. Maidenhead Deed__3. Maidenhead Su
ocr_text:
822 Early Documents

Benjamin Maplin Benjamin Maplin & Elizabeth Lee Solempnized their
marriage at the House of Thomas Revell in the
& County of Burlington the fourth day of June 1695:
before Tho: Revell Justice: And these witnesses:
Elizabeth Lee Tho: Tindall Math. Champion Robert Chapman
Robert Pearson Hugh Hutchin Willm Wardell
June 4th: 1695 Willm Spenser John Dickson Roberta Chapman
Eliz: Bingham & Alice Bingham.

The number of witnesses and the phrasing of the record suggests that
Elizabeth Lee and Benjamin Maple were members of the Society of Friends
and exchanged their vows before a'group of Quakers. The reason for writing
Benjamin's surname as "Maplin" is unknown. It may have been a slip of the
pen, or perhaps Revell knew that the surname was originally "Maplisden".

MAIDENHEAD DEED

The following is found in the New Jersey Archives, First Series, Vol.
XXI, Calendar of New Jersey Records, 1664-1703, pages 517-8:

1698-9, March 18. Deed. The West Jersey Society, by their agents, Jeremiah Basse and Thomas
Revell, to Ralph Hunt, Jno. Bainbridge, Johannes Lawrenson (Updyck), Wm. Hixon, Jno. Bryerley
(Brearley), Sam'l Hunt, Theophilus Phillips, Jonathan Davis, Tho: Smith, Jasper Smith, Tho:
Coleman, Benjamin Hardin, Wm. Akers, Robert Lannen (Lanning), Phillip Phillips, Joshua Andris,
Samuel Davis, Elnathan Davis, Enoch Andris, Comelius Andris, James Bice, John Runion
(Runyon), Thomas Runion (Runyon), Hezekiah Benham (Bonham), Benja: Maple, Lawrence
Updike, Joseph Sackett, and Edward Hunt, all of Maidenhead, Burlington Co., for 100 acres of the
Society's 15,000 acre tract above the Falls of the Delaware, to be used as a meeting house, burying
ground and Schoolhouse.

This shows that Benjamin Maple was one of the founders of Maiden-
head, Burlington Co., NJ. The name of the town was changed in 1838, and has
since been known as Lawrenceville, Mercer Co., NJ.

MAIDENHEAD SUBSCRIPTION

The following is quoted from the book by Ora Eugene Monette. First
Settlers of Ye Plantations of Piscataway and Woodbridge Olde East New Jersey
1664-1714 A period of fifty years. The Leroy Carman Press. Los Angeles,
Calif. 1930. Vol. 1,p. 113:

From the records.--The following extracts from the old town records are presented because of the
historical interest which attaches to the movements to which they refer, and also for the reason that
they contain the names of many who must have been the more prominent of the residents of the
township.

"At a Town Meeting held at Maidenhead, January Ist, 1712, the inhabitants of said town have
unanimously agreed among themselves to endeavor for the promoting of a County in the upper parts
of the prvince above Assumpinke, and in order thereto have obliged themselves seaverally and
Respectively to pay their seaveral and Respective sums of money at or before the second Day of

title: Obediah Mellott 1755-1828 bio
ocr_text:
OBEDIAH MELLOTT — Bedford Will Book 2 page 271, born 1755, died
March 28, 1828, a son of John and Sarah Mellott. He was a veteran
of the Revolutionary War serving in Capt. James Warford’s Company.
Married (1) Mary Wink died 1799, daughter of Jacob and Elizabeth
Wink, (2) Mary Daniels (daughter of Edward and Thankful Daniels)
born 1760, died May 23, 1864. Children of ist marriage: Jacob mar-
ried Abigail Mellott, daughter of John and Elizabeth Sampson
Mellott; Elizabeth married John Mellott, son of John and Elizabeth
Sampson Mellott; John married Elizabeth Sipes; Lydia married
Samuel Hockensmith; Obadiah, Jr. married Catherine Sipes; Sarah
married Jeremiah Mellott, son of John and Elizabeth Sampson
Mellott; Margaret married George Sipes; Ida married George H. Sipes;
Elias married Parthenia Hammett. Children of 2nd marriage: Mary
married Jacob Lake; Daniel married Mary Ann Deshong; Joseph mar-
ried Eva Mann; Rhoda married Elder Joseph Correll; David B. mar-
ried Elizabeth Pittman; Benjamin married Sally Waltz; Ruhama mar-
ried Robert Sipes.

title: peter johan sones history
ocr_text:
Peter Johan Sones

Memorial [ [Flowers | {edit
Learn about upgrading this memorial,
Birth: Nov. 23, 1755

Berks County
Pennsylvania, USA

Death: Nov. 3, 1850
Lycoming County
Pennsylvania, USA

He was baptized on December 18, 1755 at the
Zion Moselem Lutheran Church in Moselem
Springs, Pennsysivania. He enlisted in the
Revolutionary War in 1776 at his father's home
in Richmond Twp., Berks Co., Pennsylvania. He
served in Pennslyvania, New Jersey, and New
York. After the war he left Berks County and
moved to Moreland Twp., Lycoming County,
Pennsylvania. He applied for a pension from
the United States government in 1832 and
received the sum of $23.33 a month until his
death in 1850.

Family links:
Parents:
Johann Philip Nicholas Sohns (1719 - 1809)
‘Anna Barbara Kern Sohns (1722 - 1809)

Spouse:
Elizabetha Anna Merkel Sones (1757 - 1830)

title: James and Maud Fry. Wedding announcement
ocr_text:
Fry—Sones,

Mr. James Fry, of Northumberland
Pa., and Miss Maud V. Sones, of Ju-
lian, Pa.,. were quietly united in mar-
riage at the home of the bride’s pa-
rents at 8 o’clock last evening. The
ceremony was performed by Rev. J.
F. Tallhelm, a retired minister of the
United Brethren church. Mr. and
Mrs. Fry will make their home at
Northumberland, where he is employ-
ed in the foundry. They have the best
wishes'of every one.

Description

This database contains records for Schwaben Creek, or Himmel Lutheran and Reformed Church, which is located in Washington
Township, Northumberland County, Pennsylvania, U.S.A. Researchers may find records of baptisms, marriages, and burials for
individuals who lived in the area between 1774 and 1846. Information contained in the database includes: name, event type,
event date, relationship to person in which the record is about, church, and names of other people associated with the event.

Surname: WINKLEMAN

Given Name: Frederick P. "Fred"

Birth: 6 Nov 1840 in West Penn Twp., Union (now Snyder) Co.,
PAL

e Death: 18 Sep 1891 in Northumberland, Northumberland Co., "PA
231 of Hemorrhage

e Burial: Riverview Cemetery, Northumberland, Northumberland

Co., PA 224

* Occupation: Laborer, Farm Laborer
e Note:

Civil War service: Frederick Winkleman, Priv., Co. B.
5th Penn. Reserves; Frederick Winkleman, Priv., Co. C.,
19st Penn. Infantry.

1860 Census: Point Twp., Northumberland Co., PA (as
Winkelman) (a lodger).

1870 Census: not located.

1880 Census: Northumberland, Northumberland Co., PA
(as Winkelman).

Age 9 in 1850, 20 in 1860, 41 in 1880.

Called Simon [sic] in 1850, Fred in 1860 and 1880.
Worked as a Farm Hand in 1860, a Laborer in 1880.
Children: Susan, Samuel, and Mary.

Cemetery records (from website): Fred Winkleman, died
18 Sep 1891, age 51, of hemorrhage.

Notes and explanations by David.Myers:

At one time, it was thought that there were two different
sons, Frederick and Simon, but those names are used
interchangeably for this one son, Frederick Winkleman.

Northumberland Co., PA Pensioners, 1883 (source:
USGenWeb):

Winkelman, Frederich: res.  Northumberiand Bor.,

cause -- gunshot wound, $6/month, Mar 1876, cert.
#138312.

title: Fred Winkleman Notes
ocr_text:
"Fred" Winkelman

Simon is listed in the 1850 US PA census records as one of the children of Jacob and
Barbara Winkelman who lived in Northumberland Borough, Northumberland county, PA.
He was a known parrishoner at the United Lutheran and German Reform Church, located
in Northumberland, Northumberland county, PA where his name appeared on Sunday
morning, April 10, 1859, along with his sisters Phoebe, Barbara, and aunt Sarah
(Winkelman) Walbor at this particular Sunday's service. He was listed in the church
registry as S.F. Winkelman. One year later in April, 1860, he was listed as "Frederick"
Winkelman in the same directory. He dropped the name "Simon" just to confuse us all in
later years. For the 1860 census that year he, "Fred", appeared as a "farmhand" living
under the roof of issac Bid(d)lespach, of Point Township, Northumberland county. NOTE:
(The Biddlespachs also were noted in attandance at that same church service at the
United Lutheran Church in April, 1860 (Easter?). According to Samuel Bate's History of the
Civil War, Frederick was a Civil War Veteran and belonged to Co. B, 5th PA Reserves, 34th
Reg. from July 25, 1861 until June 6, 1864 when he was transferred to 191 Reg. PVI. His
marriage date is from the records of Rev. Billheimer who noted that Sarah was from
Watsontown. Frederick received a war pension from a gunshot wound to the right foot. In
the 1870 US PA census records Fred "Wingleman", age 30, was found in Monroe (Penns?)
Township, Snyder county, noting his occupation as "pumpmaker". This occupation would
validate his inclusion in this family. Residing with him were his wife Sarah J., age 28, and
Susan, age 1. In the 1880 US PA census records he and his wife Sarah are residing ALONE in
the Borough of Northumberland, Northumberland county, where he notes his occupation
as "laborer". Frederick is buried in Riverview Cemetery, Point Township, Northumberland
county, according to the extracted records of that cemetery; cause of death: hemorrage.
He was 51 years old. Through correspondence with Winkelman descendant Joe Coltrain in
2005, this compiler learned that Simon Frederick’s's actual birth date was Nov. 6, 1840,
and that he had (5) known children. (Question) Where were these children in the 1880
census? Only (1) was accounted for in the 1870 census. NOTE: The number of children (5)

that Fred and his wife had together was written down in Clara McCumber’s "hymnal",
dated 1837. ‘

title: Fred Winkleman - Rootsweb 3
ocr_text:
Notes from Deborah Louise (Hoffman) Weiner, Las
Vegas, NV (2001):

Frederick P. Winkelman, born abt. 1840 in Washington
Twp., Union, Pennsylvania; died 18 Sep 1891 in
Northumberland, Northumberland, Pennsylvania; buried
in Point Twp., Northumberland, Pennsylvnaia. Frederick
[called Simon] is listed as one of Jacob and Barbara
Winkelman's children in the 1850 US PA census records
for Northumberland Borough, Northumberland county,
PA. Frederick Winkelman is buried in Riverview
Cemetery, Point Twp., Northumberland county, PA,
according to the extracted records of that cemetery.
Cause of death: hemorrage. He was 51 years old.
According to Samuel Bate's History of the Civil War,
Frederick was a Civil War Veteran and belonged to Co.
B, 5th Pa. Reserves, 34th Reg. from July 25, 1861 until
June 6, 1864 when he was transferred to 191 Reg. PVI.
His marriage date is from the records of Rev. Billheimer
who noted that Sarah was from Watsontown. Frederick
received a war pension from a gunshot wound to the
right foot. He was a farmer by. occupation, but did not
own any land. In the 1860 census he was listed as living
on the farm of Issac Bid(d)lespach of Point Township, as
a farm hand. In the extracted: records of United Lutheran
and German Reformed church in Northumberland,
Northumberland county, PA, there is a listing for an F.
Winkleman who was a communicant on April 8, 1860.
(The Bidlespaches were also members of this
congregation.)

Simon Winkelman, born abt 1841 in Washington Twp.,
Union, Pennsylvania; died aft 1860 in Northumberland,
Pennsylvania; buried in, Northumberland, Pennsylvania.
Very little information on this child, other than he is
listed in the 1850 US PA census records as one of the
children of Jacob and Barbara Winkelman who lived in
Northumberland Borough, Northumberland county, PA.
He is, however, listed as a communicant at the United
Lutheran and German Reform Church, located in
Northumberland, Northumberland county, PA. His name
appeared on Sunday morning, April 10, 1859, along with
his sisters Phoebe, Barbara, and aunt Sarah (Winkelman)
Walborn at this Sunday's service.

title: Fred Winkleman - Rootsweb 2
ocr_text:
Find A Grave ( http://www. findagrave.com/ ):

Pvt Simon Frederick "Fred" Winkleman

Birth: Nov. 6, 1840, Verdilla, Snyder County,
Pennsylvania, USA

Death: Sep. 18, 1891, Northumberland, Northumberland
County, Pennsylvania, USA

Frederick was a Civil War veteran. He was wounded in
the foot. His occupation was that of a "pumpmaker", and
then later as a "laborer". His mother was Barbara
(Riegel) Winkelman, who went WEST, first to Illinois,
then to Iowa to reside with her daughter, Susanna
(Winkelman) Dale. Barbara is presumed buried in the
Arnold/Robinson Cemetery, in Urbana Township,
Monroe County, Iowa, as that is where Susanna and her
husband George Dale were buried., as well as John
Winkelman and his wife Elizabeth, who accompanied
Barbara on the trip out west.

title: TWO FAMILIES OF JOHN FRY (c1732-1819) Page 4
ocr_text:
THE TWO FAMILIES OF JOHN FRY Page 4 of 4 By Patrick Kapun: March 8, 2013
John Fry’s Will of 1809 Lists the Children of His Second Marriage

The Will of John Fry, written in 1809, identifies his children by his second wife, Anna Maria: George;
Anna Elizabeth, deceased, married to Bernhard Steer; Salome married to George Tormyer; Peter;
Henry; Andrew; Charlotta; and Anna Maria. The Confirmation records for 1805-1811 of the First
Lutheran Church in Greensburg, Westmoreland County, establish the ages of these children as follows:

e George Frey born 1779-1780 (Age 25 in 1805 Record). This disproves claims that George was
born 1772 (a presumption based on the error that John Fry married 1769 in Lancaster County).

© Peter Frey born 1782-1783 (Age 24 in 1807 Record). This agrees with the Baptism Register of
Zion Stone Church, Allen Township, Northampton County: Peter Frey, son of Johannes and
Anna Maria Frey, born December 19, 1782; baptized February 9, 1783.

e@ Maria Salome Thormayer born 1783-1784 (Age 21 in 1805 Record).

e Henrich (Henry) Frey born 1784-1785 (Age 22 in 1807 record). This agrees with the U.S. Census
records for Salem, Westmoreland: 1850-Henry Fry 66; 1860-Henry Fry 76; 1870-Henry Fry 86.

e Andereas (Andrew) Frey born 1786-1787 (Age 20 in 1807 Record). This agrees with the
Baptism Register of Salem “Big Moore” Church in Moore Township, Northampton County:
Andereas Frey, son of Johannes and Anna Maria Frey; born November 2, 1786; baptized
January 21, 1787. This agrees with the U.S. Census record for Salem: 1850-Andrew Fry Sr. 63.

e  Charlotha (Charlotte) Frey born 1791-1792 (Age 17 in 1809 Record). This agrees with the
Records of the Reformed Pastor Johann Wilhelm Weber in Westmoreland County: Scharlotta
Frey, daughter of Johannes and Anna Maria Frey; born July 18, 1791; baptized October 2, 1791.

e Anna Mary Frey born 1794-1795 (Age 16 in 1811 Record).

The ages in the confirmation records in Greensburg, Westmoreland County agree with the baptism
records in Northampton County for Peter and Andrew Frey, two of the sons of John and Anna Maria Fry.

John Fry Moved From Northampton County to Westmoreland County

John Fry sold his land in Moore Township in 1789. He last appears in the Northampton County tax
records for 1790. John Fry was not enumerated in the 1790 Census in Northampton County. John
Fry’s migration to Westmoreland County occurred around 1790, between the sale of his property in
Northampton County in 1789 and the birth of his daughter Charlotte in Westmoreland County in 1791.

It appears that Michael Frey (John Fry’s youngest son by his first wife) and Catharine Frey (John Fry’s
youngest daughter by his first wife) moved to Westmoreland County around 1790 with their father.
Michael Frey lived in Donegal (later Ligonier) Township, Westmoreland County, and died there in 1832.
Catharine Frey apparently married James Cogley in Westmoreland County.

In Westmoreland County, John Fry’s children from his second marriage married into the Bortz, Shuster,
Stier, and Thormyer families. Westmoreland County records also show the Fry name associated with
the Andre, Drum, Kepple, Klingenschmidt, Koenig, and Silvius families. It is probably not coincidental
that all of these families, like John Fry, had roots in Northampton County prior to migrating to
Westmoreland County.

title: Obituary
ocr_text:
Little, Jr, John E. of Saginaw, Michigan passed away on Tuesday, January 22, 2013. He was 91
years old. John E. Little was born on June 8, 1921 in Saginaw, Michigan to the late John E. and
Nellie (Smith) Little. He married Fern Evon Nalley on September 12, 1952. He graduated from
Saginaw High School in 1939. He then served in the United States Army during WWII with the
87th Engineering Group. Later, he went on to work for C&O (CSX) Railroad for 43 years until he
retired in 1981. He was a member of the Saginaw Masonic Lodge #77 and the 32nd Consistory
in Bay City Scottish Rite.Surviving are wife of 60 years, Fern Evon; three children, Thomas and
wife, Kathy Little, Linda and husband, Richard Shaw, and David and wife, Joyce Little; seven
grandchildren; two great-grandchildren; and many other family members and friends. FUNERAL:
A funeral will take place at 11:00 a.m. on Friday, January 25, 2013 at Deisler Funeral Home,
2233 Hemmeter (off State). Rev. James Neumann will officiate. Cremation and a private burial
will follow.VISITATION: Friends are welcome to visit at the funeral home on Thursday from 4:00
p.m. until 7:00 p.m, as well as from 10:00 a.m. until the time of service at 11:00 a.m. on Friday.
MEMORIALS: Those planning an expression of sympathy may wish to consider memorials to the
Second Presbyterian Church, 2665 Midland Road Saginaw Charter Township, MI 48603.
Arrangements are entrusted to Deisler Funeral Home.
