title: Hans Oesch, 1560-1610
ocr_text:
Hans Oesch, 1560 - 1610

Hans Oesch was born in 1560, at Steffisburg, Bern, Switzerland.

Hans married Ursula Oesch (born Sieber). 1580, at Steffisburg, Bern Switzerland.
Ursula was born 1560 in Steffisburg, Bern, Switzerland.
They had one son: Michael Oesch.

Hans passed away after 1610, at age 40 at Steffisburg, Bern, Switzerland.

title: Steffisburg History pg 2
ocr_text:
Following the 1798 lrench invasion, Steffisburg became the capital of the Helvetic

Republic Steffisburg district. After the collapse of the Republic and 1803 Act of
Mediation it joined the newly created Thun District.

The town's parish church was first built in the late 7th or early 8th century. It was
replaced with a new building in the 9th or 10th century. It was first mentioned in 1224 as
the Church of St. Stephan, which was the center of a large parish which covered the
entire Zulg river valley (Zulgtal). The bell tower was added between 1320 and 1500. In
1528, Bern adopted the new faith of the Protestant Reformation and the church at
Steffisburg converted. The attached ossuary chapel was demolished soon there after. In
the following century the Anabaptist faith became popular in the upper Zulgtal. To help
curb this faith's popularity, in 1693 a large parish church was built in Schwarzenegg (now
part of Oberlangenegg) and the Steffisburg parish divided. In 1681 the current church
building was built in Steffisburg, incorporating elements from the 9th or 10th century
building.

Traditionally the local economy was fairly diverse. The farmers raised crops on the valley
floor and raised livestock in alpine meadows during the summer before bringing them
down for the winter. By the 14th century there were vineyards on the sunny south facing
mountain slopes. The Zulg river provided power for a number of grain mills, saw mills,
fulling mills and later gunpowder mills. In the 1700s pottery factories and several brick
factories opened in the town. In 1809 a brewery opened, followed by a second in 1818.
During the 19th century the Aare and Zulg river correction projects helped drain swampy
land and protected the growing town from flooding. The town was located on the Bern-
Thun road, which was expanded in the 19th century bringing additional business to the
area. The completion of a road to the upper Emmental which passed though Steffisburg
in 1895-1900 brought more traffic and money, as did the Burgdorf-Thun railroad on 1899
and the Steffisburg-Thun-Interlaken tram in 1913. Since 1900, the town has experienced
several housing booms as commuters move to Steffisburg to be close to jobs in Thun.

In 1850 the Swiss Federal Government built the Regie in Schwabis to house horses for
cavalry for the Swiss Army. It was converted into a warehouse for military vehicles in
1982 and in 2008 became a museum that housed historic army equipment.

Steffisburg has ten kindergartens, eight primary schools and two secondary schools in a
single school district.

title: Steffisburg History pg 1
ocr_text:
Steffisburg

Steffisburg is a municipality in the administrative district of Thun in the canton of Bern
in Switzerland.

History: Steffisburg is first mentioned in 1133 as Stevensburc. The municipality was
formerly known by its French name Steffisbourg, however, that name is no longer used.

The area around Steffisburg has been inhabited since the Neolithic era and remained
occupied during the Bronze Age. Traces of a Roman site were discovered in Schwabis.
Early medieval graves have been discovered at Zelgmatte and Klosterhubel. By the High
Middle Ages the entire Zulgtal, including Steffisburg, was owned by the local Freiherr
von Heimberg family. Under the Zahringer family, the Grafschaft of Thun expanded to
include the village. When they died out in 1218 it passed to the Kyburgs, who made
Steffisburg a fief for several different Ministerialis (unfree knights in the service of a
feudal overlord) families. One of these families, the von Kien, built what became known
as the Kleine Héchhus in the 14th century, when they administered the municipality.
Today, the Kleine Héchhus is one of the oldest buildings in the municipality. Steffisburg
became the center of a local court jurisdiction. Over the following years portions of the
village and surrounding farms were donated to several local monasteries.

On 11 November 1382, Rudolf II von Kyburg, attempted unsuccessfully to attack
Solothurn. His attack started the Burgdorferkrieg (also Kyburgerkrieg) with the Old
Swiss Confederacy. Bern used the war to expand north into the Aargau and south into the
Oberland. As part of the peace treaty, Bern bought the city of Thun and all its
surrounding lands including Steffisburg. By the 15th century ownership of the town
passed from former Kyburg nobles to Bernese patricians. In 1480 the Bernese Schultheiss
Heinrich Matter built the Grosse Héchhus near the Kleine Héchhus and on the ruins of
Stevensbure castle. While the Héchhus was rebuilt several times over the centuries it
remained essentially unchanged.

Under Bernese rule, the town remained the center of a court. The court house was built in
1543 and in 1549 it became a tavern in addition to being the courthouse. While it was
part of the District of Thun, Steffisburg retained a measure of independence. They had
their own laws, which were first codified in 1405 and remained in effect until 1834. In
1476 they raised their own company of soldiers who marched under their own banner but
were under Thun's overall command. In 1553 they raised a company of riflemen who
drilled in Steffisburg, separate from Thun's military. During the 1641 and 1653 peasant
revolts the soldiers from Steffisburg rose up against the cities of Thun and Bern. Though
the revolt was unsuccessful, Steffisburg retained its position as a regional center and
court. A leader of the revolt, Hans Berger from Steffisburg, fled the country to escape
execution for his role in the uprising.

title: George Daniel Brown's Obituary
ocr_text:
K. BROWN—George “Daniel, 73,
husband of —Elfa_ (Shuman)
Brown of Nanty: Glo, passed
“away May 18,' 1965, at Lynch-

burg, Va., en route “from Flor-
ida. Friends) received after 7:30
‘p, m. Thursday, and after 3:30
p.m. Friday at Robinson-Lytle
-Funeral Home, 36 N. 7th Street,
, Indiana, :where. services. will. be
~~ eonducted” at 1:30 -p. m. Satur-
day, the Rey. Ryo: ‘E.
* Rockwell. Interment, oe
_ Cemetery, Ebensburg.

GEORGE DANIEL BROWN,
73, of Nanty Glo, passed away
Tuesday May 18, 1965, at Aes
p.m. at Lynchburg, Virginia, en-
route home from Florida.

Born December 23, 1891 in
Jackson Township, Cambria
County, he was a son of Daniel
and Esther Wilman Brown.

He was owner and operator of
a service station in Nanty Glo
prior to.his retirement five
years ago. Mr. Brown was a
‘member of the Vinco Brethren
|Church.near Johnstown. He had
been a resident of Nanty Glo,
for the past 40 years.

He is survived by his widow,
Elfa Shuman Brown, one niece
and three nephews.

Friends will be received after
3:30 p.m. Friday at Robinson-
Lytle’s, Indiana, where services
will be conducted at 1:30 p.m.
Saturday. The Rev. Raymond E,
Rockwell will officiate and inter-
ment will follow in the Lloyd
Cemetery, Ebensburg.

title: George Edward Frye b 1915 obit
ocr_text:
George E. Frye, 78, of PO Box
57, Port Matilda, died Feb. 1, 1994
at 2:09 a.m. at Centre Community
Hospital.

He was born Sept. 29, 1915 in
Armaugh, the son of James E. and
Maude (Sones) Frye.

He is survived by his long-time
companion, Phyllis Martin, Port
Matilda; two daughters: Gloria J.
Pighetti, Spruce Creek; Beverly A.
Meek, Port Matilda; two sons, Ed-
ward G., Huntingdon; Leroy W.,
Port Matilda; 13 grandchildren
and 17 great-grandchildren.

Also surviving are three sisters:

Catherine Brown, Ebensburg; Eli-
zabeth Holbert, Lewistown;
Alma Nederick, Philipsburg; two
brothers: Paul, Tyrone and Char-
sles of Ohio.
‘ He nase preceded in death by a
brother, Robert and a_ sister,
Margaret.

He was of the Methodist faith

Tyrone Daily Herald (Tyrone, Pennsylvania) «

02 Feb 1994, Wed + Page2

1 of 5 matches george e frye

George E. Frye
Port Matilda Fire Company Member

and a lifetime member of the Port
Matilda Fire Company.

In the 1940’s and 1950's, he was
a member of the square dance
band, The Bald Eagle Ramblers.

In 1980, he retired from Penn
State janitorial department after
20 years of service.

le was previously employed
at McFeeley Brick Company, Port
Matilda, for 25 years.

Private funeral services and
visitation will be held at the con-
venience of the family.

Arrangements are under the di-
rection of the Feller Memorial
Home.

In lieu of flowers, contributions
may be made to the American
Heart Association, 458 East Col-
lege Ave., State College, PA.,
16801 or Centre HomeCare, Inc.,
1300 South Allen St., State Col-
lege, PA., 16801.

title: Jacob Fry 1783-1833-37 find a grave
ocr_text:
Jacob Fry

Memorial [ Photos | Flowers |

Learn about upgrading this memorial...

Birth: 1783
Death: 1833

A note from a Fry researcher:

"This appears to be a replacement plaque for
Jacob Fry. It says a death date of 1833, but
Jacob signed his will May 17,1837, so 1833
isn't correct. In the will, several of Jacob's
children are mentioned by name, and since
this stone appears beside Eve Fry (also
mentioned in the will) I feel certain that the
will and the grave are for the same person.
Jacob's will was presented to the court in
Holmes county, Ohio 16 October 1837. See
Holmes County Wills, 1825-1869, vol A, page
59, image 67 on Family Search."

Family links:

morning, at the residence of her son-ia-law,

nue, Mrs, Mary Coho, widow of Daniel
Colo, died after an ilinessof ten weeks’ du-
ration, ‘The maiden name of the deceased
was Mary Swoveland snd ee was born in
Morrison's Cove, Bedford ‘county, July 1
1803, On September 20, 1822, she wan mar

who preceded her tothe grave some ‘years

services ‘will be held at her late home on

JAMES FRYE

James Frye of Port Matilda,
died Wednesday at 7:10 p.m,
in the Tyrone Hospital, where
he had been a patient for the
past 10 days,

He was born July 31, 1882
at Julian, Centre County, the
Son of Matlock and Elizabeth
Frye, He was married to Maude
Sones, who died in February
1966,

He is survived by these chil-
dren; Mrs, Catherine Brown,
Conemaugh RD 1; Mrs, Eliza-
beth Holbert, Lewistown; Mrs,
Margaret Devlin, Mineral Point
RD; Robert Frye and George
Frye, Port Matilda; Mrs, Wil-
lam Neidrick, Philipsburg; Paul
Frye, Port Matilda RD, andChar-
les Frye, Sunbury,

He 1s also survived by 35
grandchildren, 86 great grand-

title: George Sones obit
ocr_text:
Deaths

GEORGE SONES

George Sones, a resident of Hick- :
ory: Bottom, Taylor township, Cen-,
tre county, died at his home there
on Tuesday afternoon at 1:05 o-
clock, following a three months’ ill-
ness with heart trouble.

George Sones was a son of John
and Mary (Straw) Sones and was
born in Centre county on January ,
17, 1851. On May 14, 1885 he was
united in marriage with Miss Cath- |
arine Ramer. Mr. Sones had been’
a resident of Bald Eagle valley at’
Hickory Bottom for the past 14.
years, |

He is survived by his wife and
these children: Mys. Maude. Fry,
Port Matilda; Mrs. Sarah Fink,.
Lewistown; Roy Sones and. Mrs.:
Violet Richards, Tyrone R. D. 3;
also 23 grandchildren. i

He was a member of the Jniian |
‘Methodist Episcopal church. \

By occupation he was a carpenter.:

Funeral services will be held at
the home at Hickory Bottom on Fri- '
day afternoon at 2:30 o'clock, con-
ducted, by Rev. Robert E, Gibson, ,
pastor of the Warrior’s Mark Meth-
odist Episcopa] church, followed by
burial in the Bald Eagle cemetery. |

title: Boiler Explosion
ocr_text:
Burying Northumberland Victims
Special to The Inquirer
NORTHUMBERLAND, Feb. 5.—Busi

ness was totally suspended today during

the funerals of Duval Clark, Edward
Kreps am) Thoma« Jones, the bodies
belug interre] in Riverview Cemetery.
Four more of the victims of the Van Al-
len wire mill boiler explosion will be
burled tomorrow. Daniel Morgan, one
of the tnjured, died today.

title: 7 Victims of Boiler Explosion
ocr_text:
BOILER EXPLOSIOH
FATAL 10 SEVER;
OTHERS MAY DIE

Had Just Begun to Work
in Nail. Mills After
onut Down

BODIES OF VICTIMS

Special to The fagcirer.
NORTHUMBERLAND, Pa., Feb. 3.—
Six men were instantly Killed, another
so seriously injured that he died short-
ly afterward, and three more were prob-
ably fatally injured by an explosion
in the nail mills of Van Allen & Co.,
early this morning.
The dead are:
WILLIS CROUSE.
GRANT REEDER.
SAMUEL SARVITE,
DUYAL CLARK.
THOMAS JONES.
EDWARD KREPS.
JOHN SCHOVLIN,
The last named died in a hospital,

Those thought to be fatally injured
are: William Morgan, Harry Smith and
David Sandlers,

The heads of two of the six who met
instant death were blown off. Their
mangled and decapitated bodies were
picked up many feet from the scene of
the explosion. The exact cause of the
catastrophe is unknown.

All of the dead and injured were em-
ployed as puddlers, and were just start-
ing work, after being idle since Novem-
ber.

Had Been Closed for Repairs

The mill was closed down that exten-
sive repairs could be made. Last night
the final work was completed and all
was deemed in readiness for resumption
this morning. A, A. Johnson, the en-

gineer in charge of the boilers, made a
test of the water and steam at 6 o'clock
and reported everything in good condi-
tion, Fifteen minutes later, while the
men were beginning their daily tash,
boiler number five, of a nest of seven,
exploded with a roar that was heard for
miles. 4

The explosion was so sudden, that the
puddlers had not the least chance for es+.
cape. .it the time the men were worh-
ing on the “finng’ and “drawing” sides
of the furnace. It was at the former
side that the raw metal wae thrown intc
the caldron, and at the latter drawn,
out, sent through the “squeezer” and by
a set of rollers brought forth into natle

The first of the molten metal was being
drawn out and the men were chatting
when the force of the eaplosion hurled
scme of them into the air. The explod
ing boiler went in two directions, demol-
ishing the sidea and roof of the mull,
The sections fell in a field adjoining the
building.

Residents Jamped Irom Red

-\wahened bi the crash and seeing the
lurid glare m the shy, residents jumped
from their beds and rushed to the scene
of the calamity. Lying im ghastly posi-
tions the headless bad mangled bodies
of the unfortunate: gave mute evidence
of the explosion. The groans of the in-
jured could be heard above the roar uf

issmg steam and the commands of bose
es, Many turned away from the awful
spectacle. Others went to the assistanca
of the injured and helped to remove the
dead to # rearOy house, pressed into serv<
ice as a temporary morgue.

A burried vall was <eat to phreicians
and a number hastily responded. Through-
out the morning thousand: of people vis-
ited the wrecked mill, and the morbidly
inchned obtained relics in the shape of
nauls and pieces of the unfortunate men'<
elothing. “All of the men lulled are well
Lnown.

Coroner George W. Dreher, of Sha-
mohin. was nottied. .in inquest will be
held Thureday_

All of the victims of the catastropbe
are married men, antl sorleref-the fami-
hes are reported to be in destitute cir
cunictances.

title: Sarah J Fry divorce decree from John Ramer
ocr_text:
Sarah J. Remer by her : IN THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS OF
next friend Matlock Frye ;
3 CENTRE COUNTY,
va. :
John Ramer ; No. 3 April Term 1895,
DECREE

And now Mch, 6 1896, this oases came on to be heard on pete
ition and testimony and it appesring to the Court that the facts in
the petition set forth were true therefore upon due consideration
thereof by the Court, it was ordered, adjudged and decreed that
the seid Sarah J, Ramer complainant, be and is hereby divorced and
forever separated from the nuptial ties or bonds of matrimony with

John Ramer the Respondent and the said marriage is hereby ordered,

adjudged and decreed, to be null and void and all and every,
the duties, rights and claims accruing to either of the said part.
ies in pursuance of the said marriage, shall and do cease and
determine and it is further, ordered, adjudged and decreed that

the said John Ramer pay the costs of this proceeding.

By the Court,

COMMONWEALTH OF. PENNSYLVANIA

Decree so full and entire as the same remains of record to No,
3 April Term 1895,
IN TESTIMONY WHEREOF, I heve hereunto set my hand th fay 3 the

seal of the said Court, ay o

DEATH NOTICES

BROWN - Catherine L. (Fry), 94,
Laurel Crest Rehabilitation Center,
Ebensburg, formeriy of Jackson
Township, died July 5, 2000, at the
center. Born Dec. 20, 1905, in North
Umberland, daughter of late James
and Maude (Sones) Fry. Preceded in
death by husband, Clair; daughter,
Jessie Mellott; two brothers; two
sisters; and four grandchildren.
Survived by children, Rosella Lack,
Michigan; Leora Crawford, Nanty
Glo; Shirley Anderson, Gap, Pa.;
Marjorie Zarnesky, Ebensburg R.D.;
Ronald “Jim” Brown, Vintondale;
Catherine “Kay” Woodling, Ebens-
burg R.D.; Joyce Eckenrode and
Betty Anderson, both of Florida;
and Paulette Bracken, Strongstown.
Also survived by 43 grandchildren,
75 great-grandchildren, 21 great-
great-grandchildren, two brothers
and two sisters. Had served as a fos-
ter grandparent at Ebensburg Cen-
ter for 15 years. Friends will be re-
ceived from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Fri-
day at Askew-Houser Funeral
Homes Inc., Nanty Glo, where a fu-
neral service will be held at 11 a.m.
Saturday, the Rev. John H. Snyder

- officiating. Interment at Pike Breth-
,ren Cemetery, Mundys Corner.
